headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Towanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Towanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Philip Sherringham, President and Chief Executive Officer of People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. I am Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results this morning with Paul Burner, our CFO. Other mem
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. I am Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results this morning with Paul Burner, our CFO. Other members of our management team are here with us, and may answer questions as appropriate. I will be speaking from our quarterly slide deck, which is available under Investor Relations at www.peoples.com.Before we move on to the presentation, I'd like to remind you all to be sure to read our forward-looking statements on Slide 1. Now I'd like to start with a few comments about the current banking sector landscape prior to discussing the quarter's results. Against the backdrop of a painful multi-year global deleveraging process, the banking industry continues to be under pressure and additional consolidation can be expected. The reasons for this are clear and as follows.As we all know, of the approximately 8,500 banks in the United States, only 11 have total assets greater than $100 billion. The approximately 300 banks with asset between $1 billion and $100 billion generally share the following characteristics: assets consists primarily of loan and securities; approximately 70% of the loan book is secured by real estates and amidst of a long deleveraging cycle, housing remained depressed despite unprecedented government intervention and commercial real estate problems are just now beginning. Consumer loans represent approximately 11% of the average portfolio and commercial loans, on average, 19%. Today, both of the asset classes are generally impacted by higher credit costs, as well as reduced demand for credits.Borrowings represent 15% of liabilities on average. Non-interest revenue is just 23% of operating revenue, and capital-market activities are light to non-existent. Securities portfolio make up 25% of total assets on average and as the weakness of the economy persists, total returns will come under pressure. And last but not least, the return on average equity for the group in the third quarter of 2009 was a negative 14%.In the context of this environment, our earnings remained stable this quarter. Nonetheless, we're continuing to grow our commercial footings, while actively managing risk. Add to this mixture, a much-more-active regulatory environment, a forecast for hundreds of additional bank failures, along with increased willingness on the part of management teams of healthier banks to consider the merits of combinations and more M&A activity seems likely. Again as I noted earlier, consolidation within the bank industry is clearly necessary. The survivors will benefit from their low-cost deposit funding basis, and ability to write loans that are repaid. We continue to believe that we are well positioned for this once-in-a-generation opportunity.And so now on to Slide 2, operating net income for the fourth quarter was $28 million or $0.08 a share, excluding $4.5 million pretax or $0.01 after-tax of  non-recurring charges related to systems conversions and acquisition-related expenses. The quarter's results reflect continued growth in our core loan portfolios and deposits, despite a challenging environment. The margin held steady at $3.19 compared to the third quarter, which was up seven basis points from the second quarter of 2009. We'll speak to that in greater detail a bit later.Net loan charge-offs for the quarter decreased to 38 basis points for average loans on an annualized basis from 44 basis points in the third quarter of 2009, and were only 29 basis points for the full year. Our ratio of NPAs to loans, REO and repossessed assets moderately increased to 1.44% from 1.35% in the third quarter. I would note again, that our asset quality has held up remarkably well on both a relative and absolute basis through this most recent recessionary cycle, as we continue to enjoy limited lost content in our loan portfolio, and that most of the bad news is substantially behind us. We're pleased that our industry-leading tangible equity ratio remains strong at 18.2%. Pro forma for the pending acquisition of Financial Federal, this will increase again to 18.6%. And of course, we announced during the fourth quarter our acquisition of Financial Federal, a very attractive transaction that is immediately accretive, and which we expect to close on February 19. With that, I'll hand it over to Paul to provide you with the details of the quarter. Paul?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. Our net interest margin remained stable in the fourth quarter at 3.19%. Improvement in the spread was offset by growth in deposits. Our interests spread increased by three basis points, as liability costs dec
componenttext: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. Our net interest margin remained stable in the fourth quarter at 3.19%. Improvement in the spread was offset by growth in deposits. Our interests spread increased by three basis points, as liability costs decreased by more than the yield on earning assets. Higher average deposits of $236 million were invested in FED funds, which increased assets and offset the increase in spread, causing the margin to remain unchanged. We had a slight increase in non-performing assets in the quarter. NPAs increased nine basis points to 1.44%. Our experience is much better than others and in fact, our fourth quarter NPAs are roughly a third of those of our peers in the top 50 banks as of the third quarter. We continue to feel comfortable with our asset quality in the current environment because the strength of our initial underwriting, as well as our monitoring, resolution and loss control practices.Slide 5, provides a deeper dive into our C&I asset quality where the level of non-performers decreased somewhat during the quarter. So we saw an increase in charge-offs for the quarter. The portfolio is well diversified and continues to focus on core middle-market customers where we are able to provide better service than larger banks. Additionally, PCLC, our Equipment Finance business, finances mission-critical equipment that maintains value, coupled with our workout and resolution processes, we've been able to limit losses in this portfolio. By the way, this loss are being shared by Financial Federal as well.On Slide 6, you can see a breakout of our commercial real estate credit performance. NPA has dropped by 15 basis points to 1.34%, which is about 1/3 of the top 50 banks. And net charge-offs dropped back down to 12 basis points for the quarter. We remain comfortable with the overall quality of commercial real estate portfolio.The next slide shows a slight increase in NPAs for our mortgage portfolio to 2.7%, though charge-offs have dropped by 50% in the fourth quarter. Of the $52.7 million in mortgage NPLs, around 70% have current LTVs of less than 90%, suggesting minimal loss content for the overall portfolio. Our practice is to obtain updated appraisals at 90 days past due.  Generally, we had low average loan-to-values at origination and current FICO scores of 724. And again, I'd remind you that we stopped the portfolio in residential loans at the end of 2006.Slide 8, illustrates the credit quality trends for home equity for the fourth quarter of 2009, which remained flat compared to the third quarter. As you can see on the left of the page, the fourth quarter is 29 basis points of NPAs for us. Compares very favorably to the top 50 in our peer banks last quarter. Our net charge-offs swell up in the quarter, about 15% of the level of the top 50, and 20% of our peer group. Utilization rates are relatively steady at 48%. And we remain comfortable with this portfolio, which is an important part of our retail-customer relationships.The next slide reflects our charge-off experience over the past few years. Our loss ratio had dropped to 38 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2009 from 44 in the third. This is about 20% of both the top 50 banks in our peer group as of last quarter. We're also happy to point out that our full year charge-offs were 29 basis points. Due to our strong underwriting, we expect to continue to see minimal lost content, overall. On Slide 10, we take a look at our Texas ratio. And if you look at us relative to the industry, there continues to be no comparison. And now I'll hand it back to Philip.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. As we've done traditionally in January, we want to provide you with some thoughts on what we expect in the coming year, taking into account, of course, the FIF, Financial Federal acquisition. We expect Financial Federal or FIF to close on Fe
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. As we've done traditionally in January, we want to provide you with some thoughts on what we expect in the coming year, taking into account, of course, the FIF, Financial Federal acquisition. We expect Financial Federal or FIF to close on February 19, 2010, which is three days after the special shareholder meeting. We're looking for core incremental-commercial and consumer-loan growth of $1 billion in the year, which will be offset by an estimated $100 million of Shared National Credit run-off, an additional $430 million of residential loan amortization. Adding FIF will not significantly change our earning asset total, as those loans will be funded with what is currently cash or investments.On the deposit front, we've had strong trends at the end of 2009 with growth exceeding our expectations. For 2010, we feel we'll retain these balances. So looking at period-end over period-end, growth will be modest. But full year average growth is expected to be approximately 4%. Additionally, we expect to see a continued slight reduction in our cost of deposits during the course of the year.Now to the margin. As we've mentioned, we expect a flat rate environment for the year. However, there should be some modest benefit for the net repricing of both assets and deposits, as well as significant benefit from the addition of FIF to the loan mix. Overall, we'd expect the margin for the year to increase in this scenario by about 45 basis points. But if we're wrong and rates do rise at some point, we are very well-positioned to reap further benefits. For every 100 basis points increase in the FED funds, our net interest income would increase by $50 million on an annualized basis.Regarding asset quality, we feel our current allowance level is appropriate for the portfolio, and that we will continue to cover our charge-offs with the provision. With the close of our Financial Federal acquisition, that portfolio will come over with a full-purchase accounting mark and should not incur therefore, any additional losses.Incremental growth in FIF's portfolio, post-closing, will incur provision expense in line with our existing methodology. We would expect our covered ratio to remain approximately at 120 [ph] on the legacy portfolio. Now please keep in mind that when we announced first quarter earnings, the entire FIF portfolio, that had been marked under FAS 141(R), so this ratio will mathematically decline for the combined portfolios. Overall, fee income further increased about 2.5% with bank service charges down $7.5 million due to the headwinds associated with low overdraft fee income, offset with growth in wealth management fees and then FIF contribution.On the expense front, of course, we've continue to limit expenditures where possible, but there'll be some incremental expenses as we complete our core systems conversion to Metavante, add the operations of FIF and incur contractual occupancy and annual compensation increases. As you may know, the legacy People's United franchise, had effectively, no data processing expense beyond personnel cost, as we own our now antiquated core system. The old treatment in Franchise is on an outsourced system, which will lead to some cost savings by transitioning the entire company to Metavante. However, on a net basis, there'll still be up approximately $8 million of incremental operating expense in 2010, and approximately $15 million of one-time non-operating conversion expenses in the year. Adding in the operation of FIF, quarterly operating expenses in 2010 are likely to average about $185 million. And finally, the tax rate for 2010 is expected to be approximately 33%.So to conclude on Slide 12, I'd like again to briefly highlight a continues strength of our position. We have a very strong balance sheet with an enviable 19% tangible capital ratio and no wholesale borrowings. We have exception asset quality with a low level of non-performing loans and a very low loss content within that portfolio. We have a low-cost stable deposit base and loyal, satisfied customers. We have excellent growth opportunities ahead of us, both organically and through acquisitions. To that point, we continue to focus on seeking acquisitions within the highly-desirable Northeast region from Maine to Washington DC. We are, however, also opened the possibility of transactions in other geographies, particularly FDIC transactions to the extent, so they may now be available in the Northeast. In addition, given our asset sensitivity, we are poised to leverage earnings growth when the economy recovers and as interest rates begin to increase. That concludes our presentation. And now, we'll be happy to answer any questions you may have.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an update on what you're seeing in the way of commercial C&I loan demand? Are there any pockets of -- signs of pickup in particular geographies? And then sort of a follow-up to that, just kind of what was in the uptick in C&I charge-offs t
componenttext: Can you give us an update on what you're seeing in the way of commercial C&I loan demand? Are there any pockets of -- signs of pickup in particular geographies? And then sort of a follow-up to that, just kind of what was in the uptick in C&I charge-offs this quarter?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the loan demand by geography, I would say the Federal franchise, overall, we got stronger points and weaker points. The states of Vermont and Maine has been fairly quiet in terms of new activity, a reflection of their local economies, if
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the loan demand by geography, I would say the Federal franchise, overall, we got stronger points and weaker points. The states of Vermont and Maine has been fairly quiet in terms of new activity, a reflection of their local economies, if you will. And things have been bubblier, shall we say, in Connecticut and New York. So that's the story there. In terms of the uptick on charge-offs, there's really nothing particular. No particular sector or anything. Charge-offs in terms of C&I loans, as you know, tend to be lumpy.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And on the residential originations for sale, are you seeing any change in customer volume recently?
componenttext: And on the residential originations for sale, are you seeing any change in customer volume recently?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not particularly. Customer volume is down from the first half of the year, first half 2009, I'd say. Last year, mortgage rates are still fairly low, activities' moderate, I'd say.
componenttext: Not particularly. Customer volume is down from the first half of the year, first half 2009, I'd say. Last year, mortgage rates are still fairly low, activities' moderate, I'd say.

componenttext: And in terms of the piece you can get from the buyers, are those holding up or they...

componenttextpreview: Yes, they're holding up. So the decline in gains on sales is a function of lower volume, really.
componenttext: Yes, they're holding up. So the decline in gains on sales is a function of lower volume, really.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Collyn Gilbert with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Collyn Gilbert with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to come out of the gate, fill up with the M&A question. In terms of -- obviously, as we look at the landscape of potential deals, when we look at the banks that are on the troubled list, it seems as if the flurry of potential FDIC deals that are
componenttext: I'm going to come out of the gate, fill up with the M&A question. In terms of -- obviously, as we look at the landscape of potential deals, when we look at the banks that are on the troubled list, it seems as if the flurry of potential FDIC deals that are going to come through the pipe, and I'm talking not obviously, in the Northeast, but nationwide, will more than likely be smaller banks. The size of transactions that we've seen in the latter part of the year, maybe the supply of larger FDIC deals is not necessarily there. So given that, number one, you can dispute that point that I just made. But number two, how are you weighing what's going on within your own market? And do you see now that we've seen moderate stabilization of credit among some of the smaller regional banks, does that give you kind of the comfort and the confidence you needed to sort of expedite a potential in-market transaction?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a long question. Let me start with the fact that we're not entirely focused on FDIC-assisted transactions. Okay? Clearly, you're right. In terms of FDIC-assisted transactions, I think we'll still see a couple, maybe more than that. I'm sure larg
componenttext: Yes. It's a long question. Let me start with the fact that we're not entirely focused on FDIC-assisted transactions. Okay? Clearly, you're right. In terms of FDIC-assisted transactions, I think we'll still see a couple, maybe more than that. I'm sure larger banks somewhere in the country, sale this year. Obviously, I'm going to give you names here, but you can probably accomplish some candidates if you like to. And those may not be, probably not, are in the Northeast, so we'll see when that happens. They are still, having said that this is a likely slew of medium-sized institutions that will encounter severe problems. Now we could be looking at some of those. Having said this, I'd like to point out that we're not just looking at FDIC-assisted transactions. There are quite a few other banks of reasonably good size, I would say, that are actually interested and potentially and talking to us about a combination. So I won't limit myself to the FDIC situation. And we're talking some of those.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then in terms of just other deployment potentials for the capital. Obviously, we've got organic growth and you've got share buybacks. And I think when you guys initially did the raise in 2007 or did the conversion, you had said two- to three-year timeline
componenttext: Then in terms of just other deployment potentials for the capital. Obviously, we've got organic growth and you've got share buybacks. And I think when you guys initially did the raise in 2007 or did the conversion, you had said two- to three-year timeline for starting to deploy some of that. And maybe if not by then, you would think about buybacks. What is your view on buybacks?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I want to go back to what you just said. When we raised the capital, if I recall correctly, Collyn at the time we said, would take three to five years to deploy the capital...
componenttext: Well I want to go back to what you just said. When we raised the capital, if I recall correctly, Collyn at the time we said, would take three to five years to deploy the capital...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: To deploy it all, but I thought that you put a different time frame in terms of if there was no deals to be done in that shorter time frame that you would think about doing a buyback?
componenttext: To deploy it all, but I thought that you put a different time frame in terms of if there was no deals to be done in that shorter time frame that you would think about doing a buyback?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. After the five years, that's probably true. Having said this, we've done two deals already, we're working on others. And I think, I'm fairly confident, we'll be able to do one or more deals before the expiration of the five-year time frame, if you'
componenttext: Right. After the five years, that's probably true. Having said this, we've done two deals already, we're working on others. And I think, I'm fairly confident, we'll be able to do one or more deals before the expiration of the five-year time frame, if you'd like. Having said this, obviously, buybacks, is always an option in terms of returning capital. I do want to point out that we have a very healthy dividend. As you know, we're one of the few banks that actually increased their dividends last year. And that's another way of returning capital. And I believe our shareholders generally appreciate it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again if we've seen moderate stabilization in the Northeast, in the economy, does this change your view and your appetite for risk, as it relates to organic growth?
componenttext: Again if we've seen moderate stabilization in the Northeast, in the economy, does this change your view and your appetite for risk, as it relates to organic growth?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. I mean, our appetite for risk, our underwriting criteria have been very stable over time. And that's, as you know, of course, for us, is a great position. I think it's frankly a bit premature, at this point, given what we've seen in the e
componenttext: Not necessarily. I mean, our appetite for risk, our underwriting criteria have been very stable over time. And that's, as you know, of course, for us, is a great position. I think it's frankly a bit premature, at this point, given what we've seen in the economy to declare a victory and loosen up dramatically. I just don't think it's reasonable. I also don't think it's necessary because frankly, we're all getting a slew of opportunities in terms of loans -- very attractive pricing, very attractive credits. We don't particularly need to loosen underwriting to get more volume, and I don't think it would be wise yet.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Weiss with Janney.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Weiss with Janney.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the pending acquisition, FIF. For a start, is there any different like kind of cultural issues with regard to the lending standards that they have compared to the People's franchise?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the pending acquisition, FIF. For a start, is there any different like kind of cultural issues with regard to the lending standards that they have compared to the People's franchise?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well one of the strengths of that franchise, as you know, is historically, they're great at asset quality. They survived the turmoil in their industry by sticking to anything and focusing on credit very heavily. I think you know the way they approach the
componenttext: Well one of the strengths of that franchise, as you know, is historically, they're great at asset quality. They survived the turmoil in their industry by sticking to anything and focusing on credit very heavily. I think you know the way they approach the business is a little different from the way we do. And generally, I'd say that they tend to take a bit more credit risk and they get higher returns. But the trade-off works. And so when we closed the deal, the plan is to keep them operating just the way they are, essentially. On a decentralized basis, if you will.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you brought up 141(R), so you marked them to fair value. What do you expect the margin to do as a result of that?
componenttext: When you brought up 141(R), so you marked them to fair value. What do you expect the margin to do as a result of that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well the mark is basically a credit mark in this case. okay? So the impact is that if we got the mark right and this applies to everyone in the industry by the way, in terms of acquisition, in terms of accounting standard, we've got the mark right, that p
componenttext: Well the mark is basically a credit mark in this case. okay? So the impact is that if we got the mark right and this applies to everyone in the industry by the way, in terms of acquisition, in terms of accounting standard, we've got the mark right, that particular portfolio should not have any more losses in it. And in fact, if we're overly conservative, over time, we'll get it back, of course. The impact on the margin of the FIF acquisition, I highlighted in my comments, we expect the margin to go up about 45 basis points as a result of the acquisition.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now that's because the yield is higher right now and not because of the purchase accounting adjustments then?
componenttext: Now that's because the yield is higher right now and not because of the purchase accounting adjustments then?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. Two things, the yield on the asset is higher and of course, we're substituting our cost of funds with their cost of funds, which is a pretty  significant difference. I point out, by the way, that our cost of deposits in December was 85 bas
componenttext: That's correct. Two things, the yield on the asset is higher and of course, we're substituting our cost of funds with their cost of funds, which is a pretty  significant difference. I point out, by the way, that our cost of deposits in December was 85 basis points, which is lower than the average for the quarter which was 94 basis points. And their cost of funds, last time I checked, was about $360 million, $370 million at Financial Federal. So that's going to go, we'll replace it with our cost of funds. You can see the huge pick up their, which helps the margins, of course, a lot. A longer high yields on the asset side.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

componenttext: Was your funding relatively short? Will it roll over quickly?

componenttext: Yes. We're going to pay that out almost immediately.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

componenttext: Just staying with the FIF for a minute, if you look at the loan balances there that have been coming down 7% or 8% a quarter, where do you expect the final acquired-loan balance to be relative to the $1.5 billion that was modeled when you announced it in November?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we expect it to be somewhat lower. I'd say probably about close to $1.4 billion.
componenttext: Well we expect it to be somewhat lower. I'd say probably about close to $1.4 billion.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the pace of decline begin to moderate? Are you stepping in to kind of re-enforce...
componenttext: So the pace of decline begin to moderate? Are you stepping in to kind of re-enforce...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the pace of decline was a function, I think, of the economy itself. The fact that many of those OEMs, people like Caterpillar and so on, saw a reduced sale and therefore, a reduced need for financing their equipment, obviously. So I think as the econ
componenttext: Yes, the pace of decline was a function, I think, of the economy itself. The fact that many of those OEMs, people like Caterpillar and so on, saw a reduced sale and therefore, a reduced need for financing their equipment, obviously. So I think as the economy eventually picks up, you'll see a turnaround there. I'd also like to suggest that obviously, in their prior environment, Fin Fed [Financial Federal] had funding constraints. And they managed that situation pretty well. Having said this, if you remove the funding constraints, which what our transaction will do for them, they'll have more opportunity to grow the business, clearly. Without being concerned about finding the funding or guaranteeing the funding and so on.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the expense guidance, the 185, what is the full year expense low that you're including for FIF? They were running about $10 billion a quarter, so the full $40 million or is there any synergies at all or...
componenttext: And then on the expense guidance, the 185, what is the full year expense low that you're including for FIF? They were running about $10 billion a quarter, so the full $40 million or is there any synergies at all or...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: $30 million corresponds for the 185. There may be a little opportunity there, but really the acquisition synergies aren't built on expense reductions.
componenttext: $30 million corresponds for the 185. There may be a little opportunity there, but really the acquisition synergies aren't built on expense reductions.

componenttext: So it implies kind of a $20 million or $30 million actually, $30 million to $40 million increase in kind of core People's expenses on this embedded in that 185 guidance?

componenttext: Yes, that's probably right. Yes.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Philip, could you just talk a little bit about the increase in OREO this quarter and what led to that?
componenttext: Philip, could you just talk a little bit about the increase in OREO this quarter and what led to that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Towanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Towanda, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Mr. Philip Sherringham, President and Chief Executive Officer of People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. I am Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results this morning with Paul Burner, our CFO. Other mem
componenttext: Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. I am Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results this morning with Paul Burner, our CFO. Other members of our management team are here with us, and may answer questions as appropriate. I will be speaking from our quarterly slide deck, which is available under Investor Relations at www.peoples.com.Before we move on to the presentation, I'd like to remind you all to be sure to read our forward-looking statements on Slide 1. Now I'd like to start with a few comments about the current banking sector landscape prior to discussing the quarter's results. Against the backdrop of a painful multi-year global deleveraging process, the banking industry continues to be under pressure and additional consolidation can be expected. The reasons for this are clear and as follows.As we all know, of the approximately 8,500 banks in the United States, only 11 have total assets greater than $100 billion. The approximately 300 banks with asset between $1 billion and $100 billion generally share the following characteristics: assets consists primarily of loan and securities; approximately 70% of the loan book is secured by real estates and amidst of a long deleveraging cycle, housing remained depressed despite unprecedented government intervention and commercial real estate problems are just now beginning. Consumer loans represent approximately 11% of the average portfolio and commercial loans, on average, 19%. Today, both of the asset classes are generally impacted by higher credit costs, as well as reduced demand for credits.Borrowings represent 15% of liabilities on average. Non-interest revenue is just 23% of operating revenue, and capital-market activities are light to non-existent. Securities portfolio make up 25% of total assets on average and as the weakness of the economy persists, total returns will come under pressure. And last but not least, the return on average equity for the group in the third quarter of 2009 was a negative 14%.In the context of this environment, our earnings remained stable this quarter. Nonetheless, we're continuing to grow our commercial footings, while actively managing risk. Add to this mixture, a much-more-active regulatory environment, a forecast for hundreds of additional bank failures, along with increased willingness on the part of management teams of healthier banks to consider the merits of combinations and more M&A activity seems likely. Again as I noted earlier, consolidation within the bank industry is clearly necessary. The survivors will benefit from their low-cost deposit funding basis, and ability to write loans that are repaid. We continue to believe that we are well positioned for this once in a [ph] generation opportunity.And so now on to Slide 2, operating net income for the fourth quarter was $28 million or $0.08 a share, excluding $4.5 million pretax or $0.01 after-tax of  non-recurring charges related to systems conversions and acquisition-related expenses. The quarter's results reflect continued growth in our core loan portfolios and deposits, despite a challenging environment. The margin held steady at $3.19 compared to the third quarter, which was up seven basis points from the second quarter of 2009. We'll speak to that in greater detail a bit later.Net loan charge-offs for the quarter decreased to 38 basis points for average loans on an annualized basis from 44 basis points in the third quarter of 2009, and were only 29 basis points for the full year. Our ratio of NPAs to loans, REO and repossessed assets moderately increased to 1.44% from 1.35% in the third quarter. I would note again, that our asset quality has held up remarkably well on both a relative and absolute basis through this most recent recessionary cycle, as we continue to enjoy limited lost content in our loan portfolio, and that most of the bad news is substantially behind us. We're pleased that our industry-leading tangible equity ratio remains strong at 18.2%. Pro forma for the pending acquisition of Financial Federal, this will increase again to 18.6%. And of course, we announced during the fourth quarter our acquisition of Financial Federal, a very attractive transaction that is immediately accretive, and which we expect to close on February 19. With that, I'll hand it over to Paul to provide you with the details of the quarter. Paul?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. Our net interest margin remained stable in the fourth quarter at 3.19%. Improvement in the spread was offset by growth in deposits. Our interests spread increased by three basis points, as liability costs dec
componenttext: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. Our net interest margin remained stable in the fourth quarter at 3.19%. Improvement in the spread was offset by growth in deposits. Our interests spread increased by three basis points, as liability costs decreased by more than the yield on earning assets. Higher average deposits of $236 million were invested in Fed funds, which increased assets and offset the increase in spread, causing the margin to remain unchanged. We had a slight increase in non-performing assets in the quarter. NPAs increased nine basis points to 1.44%. Our experience is much better than others and in fact, our fourth quarter NPAs are roughly a third of those of our peers in the top 50 banks as of the third quarter. We continue to feel comfortable with our asset quality in the current environment because the strength of our initial underwriting, as well as our monitoring, resolution and loss control practices.Slide 5, provides a deeper dive into our C&I asset quality where the level of non-performers decreased somewhat during the quarter, though we saw an increase in charge-offs for the quarter. The portfolio is well diversified and continues to focus on core middle-market customers where we are able to provide better service than larger banks. Additionally, PCLC, our Equipment Finance business, finances mission-critical equipment that maintains value, coupled with our workout and resolution processes, we've been able to limit losses in this portfolio. By the way, this loss are being shared by Financial Federal as well.On Slide 6, you can see a breakout of our commercial real estate credit performance. NPA has dropped by 15 basis points to 1.34%, which is about 1/3 of the top 50 banks. And net charge-offs dropped back down to 12 basis points for the quarter. We remain comfortable with the overall quality of our commercial real estate portfolio.The next slide shows a slight increase in NPAs for our mortgage portfolio to 2.07%, though charge-offs have dropped by 50% in the fourth quarter. Of the $52.7 million in mortgage NPLs, around 70% have current LTVs of less than 90%, suggesting minimal loss content for the overall portfolio. Our practice is to obtain updated appraisals at 90 days past due.  Generally, we had low average loan-to-values at origination and current FICO scores of 724. And again, I'd remind you that we stopped the portfolio in residential loans at the end of 2006.Slide 8, illustrates the credit quality trends for home equity for the fourth quarter of 2009, which remained flat compared to the third quarter. As you can see on the left of the page, the fourth quarter is 29 basis points of NPAs for us. Compares very favorably to the top 50 in our peer banks last quarter. Our net charge-offs swell up in the quarter, about 15% of the level of the top 50, and 20% of our peer group. Utilization rates are relatively steady at 48%. And we remain comfortable with this portfolio, which is an important part of our retail-customer relationships.The next slide reflects our charge-off experience over the past few years. Our loss ratio dropped to 38 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2009 from 44 in the third. This is about 20% of both the top 50 banks in our peer group as of last quarter. We're also happy to point out that our full year charge-offs were 29 basis points. Due to our strong underwriting, we expect to continue to see minimal lost content, overall. On Slide 10, we take a look at our Texas ratio. And if you look at us relative to the industry, there continues to be no comparison. And now I'll hand it back to Philip.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. As we've done traditionally in January, we want to provide you with some thoughts on what we expect in the coming year, taking into account, of course, the FIF, Financial Federal acquisition. We expect Financial Federal or FIF to close on Fe
componenttext: Thanks, Paul. As we've done traditionally in January, we want to provide you with some thoughts on what we expect in the coming year, taking into account, of course, the FIF, Financial Federal acquisition. We expect Financial Federal or FIF to close on February 19, 2010, which is three days after the special shareholder meeting. We're looking for core incremental-commercial and consumer-loan growth of $1 billion in the year, which will be offset by an estimated $100 million of Shared National Credit run-off, an additional $430 million of residential loan amortization. Adding FIF will not significantly change our earning asset total, as those loans will be funded with what is currently cash or investments.On the deposit front, we've had strong trends at the end of 2009 with growth exceeding our expectations. For 2010, we feel we'll retain these balances. So looking at period-end over period-end, growth will be modest. But full year average growth is expected to be approximately 4%. Additionally, we expect to see a continued slight reduction in our cost of deposits during the course of the year.Now to the margin. As we've mentioned, we expect a flat rate environment for the year. However, there should be some modest benefit for the net repricing of both assets and deposits, as well as significant benefit from the addition of FIF to the loan mix. Overall, we'd expect the margin for the year to increase in this scenario by about 45 basis points. But if we're wrong and rates do rise at some point, we are very well-positioned to reap further benefits. For every 100 basis points increase in the FED funds, our net interest income would increase by $50 million on an annualized basis.Regarding asset quality, we feel our current allowance level is appropriate for the portfolio, and that we will continue to cover our charge-offs with the provision. With the close of our Financial Federal acquisition, that portfolio will come over with a full-purchase accounting mark and should not incur therefore, any additional losses.Incremental growth in FIF's portfolio, post-closing, will incur provision expense in line with our existing methodology. We would expect our covered ratio to remain approximately at 120 [ph] on the legacy portfolio. Now please keep in mind that when we announced first quarter earnings, the entire FIF portfolio, that had been marked under FAS 141(R), so this ratio will mathematically decline for the combined portfolios. Overall, fee income further increased about 2.5% with bank service charges down $7.5 million due to the headwinds associated with low overdraft fee income, offset with growth in wealth management fees and then FIF contribution.On the expense front, of course, we've continue to limit expenditures where possible, but there'll be some incremental expenses as we complete our core systems conversion to Metavante, add the operations of FIF and incur contractual occupancy and annual compensation increases. As you may know, the legacy People's United franchise, had effectively, no data processing expense beyond personnel cost, as we own our now antiquated core system. The old thread [ph]  Franchise is on an outsourced system, which will lead to some cost savings by transitioning the entire company to Metavante. However, on a net basis, there'll still be up approximately $8 million of incremental operating expense in 2010, and approximately $15 million of one-time non-operating conversion expenses in the year. Adding in the operation of FIF, quarterly operating expenses in 2010 are likely to average about $185 million. And finally, the tax rate for 2010 is expected to be approximately 33%.So to conclude on Slide 12, I'd like again to briefly highlight a continues strength of our position. We have a very strong balance sheet with an enviable 19% tangible capital ratio and no wholesale borrowings. We have exception asset quality with a low level of non-performing loans and a very low loss content within that portfolio. We have a low-cost stable deposit base and loyal, satisfied customers. We have excellent growth opportunities ahead of us, both organically and through acquisitions. To that point, we continue to focus on seeking acquisitions within the highly-desirable Northeast region from Maine to Washington DC. We are, however, also opened the possibility of transactions in other geographies, particularly FDIC transactions to the extent, so they may now be available in the Northeast. In addition, given our asset sensitivity, we are poised to leverage earnings growth when the economy recovers and as interest rates begin to increase. That concludes our presentation. And now, we'll be happy to answer any questions you may have.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the loan demand by geography, I would say the Federal franchise, overall, we got stronger points and weaker points. The states of Vermont and Maine has been fairly quiet in terms of new activity, a reflection of their local economies, if
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the loan demand by geography, I would say the Federal franchise, overall, we got stronger points and weaker points. The states of Vermont and Maine has been fairly quiet in terms of new activity, a reflection of their local economies, if you will. And things have been bubblier, shall we say, in Connecticut and New York. So that's the story there. In terms of the uptick on charge-offs, there's really nothing particular. No particular sector or anything. Charge-offs in terms of C&I loans, as you know, tend to be lumpy.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to come out of the gate, fill up with the M&A question. In terms of -- obviously, as we look at the landscape of potential deals, when we look at the banks that are on the troubled list, it seems as if the flurry of potential FDIC deals that are
componenttext: I'm going to come out of the gate, fill up with the M&A question. In terms of -- obviously, as we look at the landscape of potential deals, when we look at the banks that are on the troubled list, it seems as if the flurry of potential FDIC deals that are going to come through the pipe, and I'm talking not obviously, in the Northeast, but nationwide, will more than likely be smaller banks. The size of transactions that we've seen in the latter part of the year, maybe the supply of larger FDIC deals is not necessarily there. So given that, number one, you can dispute that point that I just made. But number two, how are you weighing what's going on within your own market? And do you see now that we've seen moderate stabilization of credit among some of the smaller regional banks, does that give you kind of the comfort and the confidence you needed to sort of expedite a potential in-market transaction?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It's a long question. Let me start with the fact that we're not entirely focused on FDIC-assisted transactions. Okay? Clearly, you're right. In terms of FDIC-assisted transactions, I think we'll still see a couple, maybe more than that. I'm sure larg
componenttext: Yes. It's a long question. Let me start with the fact that we're not entirely focused on FDIC-assisted transactions. Okay? Clearly, you're right. In terms of FDIC-assisted transactions, I think we'll still see a couple, maybe more than that. I'm sure larger banks somewhere in the country, sale this year. Obviously, I'm going to give you names here, but you can probably accomplice [ph] some candidates if you like to. And those may not, probably not, are in the Northeast, so we'll see when that happens. They are still, having said that this is a likely slew of medium-sized institutions that will encounter severe problems. Now we could be looking at some of those. Having said this, I'd like to point out that we're not just looking at FDIC-assisted transactions. There are quite a few other banks of reasonably good size, I would say, that are actually interested and potentially and talking to us about a combination. So I won't limit myself to the FDIC situation. And we're talking some of those.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then in terms of just other deployment potentials for the capital. Obviously, we've got organic growth and you've got share buybacks. And I think when you guys initially did the raise in 2007 or did the conversion, you had said two- to three-year timeline
componenttext: Then in terms of just other deployment potentials for the capital. Obviously, we've got organic growth and you've got share buybacks. And I think when you guys initially did the raise in 2007 or did the conversion, you had said two- to three-year timeline for starting to deploy some of that. And maybe if not by then, you would think about buybacks. What is your view on buybacks?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I want to go back to what you just said. When we raised the capital, if I recall correctly, Collyn at the time we said, would take three to five years to deploy the capital...
componenttext: Well I want to go back to what you just said. When we raised the capital, if I recall correctly, Collyn at the time we said, would take three to five years to deploy the capital...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: To deploy it all, but I thought that you put a different time frame in terms of if there was no deals to be done and that sort of time frame that you would think about doing a buyback?
componenttext: To deploy it all, but I thought that you put a different time frame in terms of if there was no deals to be done and that sort of time frame that you would think about doing a buyback?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. After the five years, that's probably true. Having said this, we've done two deals already, we're working on others. And I think, I'm fairly confident, we'll be able to do one or more deals before the expiration of the five-year time frame, if you'
componenttext: Right. After the five years, that's probably true. Having said this, we've done two deals already, we're working on others. And I think, I'm fairly confident, we'll be able to do one or more deals before the expiration of the five-year time frame, if you'd like. Having said this, obviously, buybacks, is always an option in terms of returning capital. I do want to point out that we have a very healthy dividend. As you know, we're one of the few banks that actually increased their dividends last year. And that's another way of returning capital. And I believe our shareholders generally appreciate it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again if we've seen moderate stabilization in the Northeast, in the economy, does this change your view and your appetite for risk, as it relates to organic growth?
componenttext: Again if we've seen moderate stabilization in the Northeast, in the economy, does this change your view and your appetite for risk, as it relates to organic growth?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not necessarily. I mean, our appetite for risk, our underwriting criteria have been very stable over time. And that's, as you know, of course, for us, is a great position. I think it's frankly a bit premature, at this point, given what we've seen in the e
componenttext: Not necessarily. I mean, our appetite for risk, our underwriting criteria have been very stable over time. And that's, as you know, of course, for us, is a great position. I think it's frankly a bit premature, at this point, given what we've seen in the economy to declare a victory and loosen up dramatically. I just don't think it's reasonable. I also don't think it's necessary because frankly, we're all getting a slew of opportunities in terms of loans -- very attractive pricing, very attractive credits. We don't particularly need to loosen underwriting to get more volume, and I don't think it would be wise yet.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Weiss with Janney [Janney Montgomery].

componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the pending acquisition, FIF. For a start, is there any different like kind of cultural issues with regard to the lending standards that they have compared to the People's franchise?
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the pending acquisition, FIF. For a start, is there any different like kind of cultural issues with regard to the lending standards that they have compared to the People's franchise?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well one of the strengths of that franchise, as you know, is historically, their great at asset quality. They survived the turmoil in their industry by sticking to anything and focusing on credit very heavily. I think you know the way they approach the bu
componenttext: Well one of the strengths of that franchise, as you know, is historically, their great at asset quality. They survived the turmoil in their industry by sticking to anything and focusing on credit very heavily. I think you know the way they approach the business is a little different from the way we do. And generally, I'd say that they tend to take a bit more credit risk and they get higher returns. But the trade-off works. And so when we closed the deal, the plan is to keep them operating just the way they are, essentially. On a decentralized basis, if you will.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

componenttext: Well the mark is basically a credit mark in this case. okay? So the impact is that if we got the mark right and this applies to everyone in the industry by the way, in terms of acquisition, in terms of accounting standard, we've got the mark right, that particular portfolio should not have any more losses in it. And in fact, if we're overly conservative, over time, we'll get it back, of course. The impact on the margin of the FIF acquisition, I highlighted in my comments, we expect the margin to go up about 45 basis points as a result of the acquisition.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now that's because the yield is higher right now and not because of the purchase accounting adjustments then?
componenttext: Now that's because the yield is higher right now and not because of the purchase accounting adjustments then?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct. Two things, the yield on the asset is higher and of course, we're substituting our cost of funds with their cost of funds, which is a pretty  significant difference. I point out, by the way, that our cost of deposits in December was 85 bas
componenttext: That's correct. Two things, the yield on the asset is higher and of course, we're substituting our cost of funds with their cost of funds, which is a pretty  significant difference. I point out, by the way, that our cost of deposits in December was 85 basis points, which is lower than the average for the quarter which was 94 basis points. And their cost of funds, last time I checked, was about $360 million, $370 million at Financial Federal. So that's going to go, we'll replace it with our cost of funds. You can see the huge pick up there, which helps the margins, of course, a lot. A longer high yields on the asset side.

componenttextpreview: Yes, [indiscernible] the pace of decline was a function, I think, of the economy itself. The fact that many of those OEMs, people like Caterpillar and so on, saw a reduced sale and therefore, a reduced need for financing their equipment, obviously. So I t
componenttext: Yes, [indiscernible] the pace of decline was a function, I think, of the economy itself. The fact that many of those OEMs, people like Caterpillar and so on, saw a reduced sale and therefore, a reduced need for financing their equipment, obviously. So I think as the economy eventually picks up, you'll see a turnaround there. I'd also like to suggest that obviously, in their prior environment, Fin Fed [Financial Federal] had funding constraints. And they managed that situation pretty well. Having said this, if you remove the funding constraints, which what our transaction will do for them, they'll have more opportunity to grow the business, clearly. Without being concerned about finding the funding or guaranteeing the funding and so on.

componenttext: Yes. That's sort of the fallback positions, if you will. We actually have plans to open a branch in the Boston market in Wesley, this year. So that's an example of that. componenttext: No, it's just timing of flows. We've had very good deposit growth all year. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Carla, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to y
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Inc. First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Carla, and I'll be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today, Mr. Philip Sherringham, President and Chief Executive Officer of People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome, of course, to the First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. Again, I'm Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results today with Paul Burner,
componenttext:
Yes, thank you. Good morning, everyone, and welcome, of course, to the First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call of People's United Financial. Again, I'm Philip Sherringham, President and CEO, and I will be presenting our results today with Paul Burner, our CFO. Other members of our management team are here with us and may answer questions as appropriate. I will be speaking from our quarterly slide deck, which is available under Investor Relations at www.peoples.com.
As you all have seen in our earnings release, we're pleased to report that People's United continues to benefit from its fortress balance sheet characterized by a strong capital position and ongoing solid asset quality. We continue to grow our Commercial portfolio during the quarter while managing risk. 
Other highlights of the quarter include the closing and integration of Financial Federal. This integration, which is substantially complete, has so far progressed very smoothly, and the operations immediately began adding to the bottom line.
Second, the successful conversion of our Southern New England franchise onto a new FIS Metavante core systems platform, reflecting a tremendous amount of time and effort by employees toward the bank. This is something our investors don't see on a day-to-day basis, but it's a very important component of our growth strategy. It provide significant operating efficiencies and allows us to continue to offer the award-winning customer service for which we're known. We're looking forward to the conversion of our Northern New England franchise in July. After which time, our entire franchise will be on one core system.
Finally, a continued active due diligence process on both open banks and FDIC opportunities. We remain convinced that the best deployment of our excess capital is an FDIC assisted and whole-bank acquisitions in attractive markets with high population density. While it's difficult to predict with certainty, we are pursuing a number of opportunities and feel confident that we'll have an announcement in the near future. Before we move on to the presentation, I'd like to remind you please to all be sure to read our forward-looking statements on Slide 1. 
And now on to Slide 2. Operating net income for the first quarter was $29.2 million or $0.08 a share, excluding $23.4 million pretax or $0.04 a share after tax of non-recurring charges related to system conversion and acquisition-related expenses. The quarter's results reflect continued growth in our core Loan portfolios and deposits despite the challenging environment.
Our margin benefited from the Financial Federal acquisition, increasing to 3.47%, compared to fourth quarter's 3.19%. We'll speak to that in greater detail a bit later. Net Loan charge-offs for the quarter decreased to 26 basis points of average loans on an annualized basis from 38 basis points in the fourth quarter 2009, which was our second consecutive quarterly decline in net charge-offs. On the other hand, due to continued economic weakness in our markets, our ratio of NPAs to originated loans, REO and repossessed assets did increase to 1.74% from 1.44% in the fourth quarter. 
I would note again that our asset quality has held up remarkably well on both a relative and absolute basis through this most recent recession that we continue to enjoy limited loss content in our Loan portfolio and that most of the bad news is substantially behind us. We're pleased that our industry-leading tangible equity ratio remained strong at 18.6%, and actually increased 40 basis points as a result of the addition of Financial Federal. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Paul to provide you with details on the quarter. Paul?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. As Philip mentioned, our overall net interest margin increased to 3.47%, up 28 basis points from the 3.19% in the fourth quarter. Improvement in the spread was primarily due to higher yields in our Loan portf
componenttext:
Thank you, Philip, and good morning, everyone. As Philip mentioned, our overall net interest margin increased to 3.47%, up 28 basis points from the 3.19% in the fourth quarter. Improvement in the spread was primarily due to higher yields in our Loan portfolio due to the acquisition of Financial Federal, as well as the reduction in deposit costs. Deposit costs of 78 basis points in the first quarter were down 16 basis points from the 94 basis points in the fourth quarter of 2009. For the month of March, our margin was 3.76%, which reflected the benefit of Financial Federal for the whole month. Therefore, we expect further improvement in the margin for the second quarter.
Moving on to Slide 4, as unemployment remains high and the economy remains weak, we saw an additional increase in non-performing assets in the quarter. NPAs increased to 1.74% from 1.44% of Loans and REO. As you can see in the footnote, due to the acquisition of Fin Fed and the 141(r) credit mark on their portfolio, we're presenting this information as a ratio of NPAs to originated loans. However, the NPAs do include acquired repossessed assets from Fin Fed. Our experience remains much better than others as you can see. And because of the strength of our original underwriting, as well as our monitoring resolution and loss control practices, we continue to feel comfortable with our asset quality in the current environment. 
As we've done in the past, Slide 5 provides a deeper dive into our Commercial and Equipment Financing asset quality. Again, due to the credit mark, the loans acquired from Fin Fed are fully marked. However, going forward, new loans originated since the acquisition will be included here in NPLs as warranted. While NPLs increased in the quarter, you can see that our losses decreased and remained very manageable at 15 basis points, annualized for the quarter. The portfolio is well diversified and continues to focus on core middle-market customers, where we're able to provide better service than larger banks. Additionally, our Equipment Financing business has financed mission-critical equipment that maintains value. Coupled with our work-out and resolution processes, we've been able to limit losses in this portfolio.
On Slide 6, you can see a breakout of our Commercial Real Estate credit performance. NPLs continue to decline for the second consecutive quarter to 1.21%, while net charge-offs increased to 43 basis points annualized, reflecting $4.3 million of higher charge-offs. We expect that there continue to be some choppiness as we've seen in the past few quarters to this ratio given the size of Commercial Real Estate loans. Construction loan balances continue to decline and are now about 5% of total loans.
Residential loans continue to run off. And as this portfolio declines, we would anticipate NPLs as a percentage to increase. However, actual loss content remains very low. This quarter, while NPLs rose to $66.7 million or 2.7% of Residential loans, net charge-offs were only one basis point. Looking at the group of NPLs, approximately 70% have current loan-to-values less than 90%, which is consistent with last quarter and suggests to our continued low loss content in the portfolio. Generally, we had low average loan-to-values at origination and current FICO scores of 721. I would also remind you that we stopped portfolioing Residential loans at the end of 2006.
Slide 8 illustrates credit quality trends for Home Equity for the first quarter of 2010, which remained similar compared to the fourth quarter. As you can see on the left of the page, the first quarter's 35 basis points of NPLs for us compares very favorably to both the Top 50 and our peer banks last quarter. Our net charge-offs declined in the quarter and are less than 10% of the level of the Top 50 and of our peer group. Utilization rates are steady at 48%. While growth in this portfolio has moderated due to customer preference over the past few quarters, we continue to feel this is an important part of our retail customer relationships.
We're especially proud of the data on the next slide, which reflects our charge-off experience over the past few years. As you know, banking is about managing risks, and I think this shows that we do that very well. Our loss ratio dropped to 26 basis points in the first quarter of 2010 from 38 in the fourth, and this is about 10% of the Top 50 banks and 13% of our peer group as of last quarter. Due to our strong underwriting, we expect to continue to see minimal loss content overall.
Slide 10, we take a look at our taxes ratio. As you know, this is a measure of credit compared to capital, both very important items to our bank. If you look at us relative to the industry, there continues to be no comparison.
Moving on to Slide 11, we want to take a brief moment to highlight our asset-sensitive position. We remain one of if not the most asset-sensitive bank in the country. This has been a burden as we live through this period of very low rates, but will be a benefit to us as rates begin to rise at some point in the future. Some have tried to discount this by arguing that our asset sensitivity derives solely from our excess capital. And once it's deployed, the benefit will evaporate. Well, while half of our asset sensitivity is indeed due to the excess capital of approximately $2.5 million, the other half is due to the structure of our balance sheet, which has not changed. Any rate increase will flow to the bottom line, increasing earnings whether that capital is deployed or not. So as you all look out and ponder a higher rate environment, don't forget that we will stand to win in such an environment. And now I'll hand it back to Philip.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul. As we look at this conclusion slide, I want to point out that while these conclusions are familiar to most of you, they do reflect our patience and discipline, which remain hallmarks of how we are managing this institution. We feel that o
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul. As we look at this conclusion slide, I want to point out that while these conclusions are familiar to most of you, they do reflect our patience and discipline, which remain hallmarks of how we are managing this institution. We feel that our time has come, and we will be rewarded for this patience and discipline as we progress to 2010. 
To conclude on Slide 12, I'd like to briefly highlight the continued strength of our position. We have a very strong balance sheet with an enviable 19% tangible capital ratio and no wholesale borrowings. We have exceptional asset quality with a low level of non-performing loans, and a very low loss content within that portfolio. We have a low-cost, stable deposit base and loyal satisfied customers. We have excellent growth opportunities ahead of us, both organically and through acquisitions. To that point, we continue to focus on seeking acquisitions within geographies that are both wealth and population density. We feel these transactions could be in the form of open-bank transactions, as well as FDIC-assisted deals. In addition, as Paul just pointed out, our asset sensitivity provides significant earnings and operating leverage as interest rates begin to increase.
This concludes our presentation. And now we'll be happy to answer any questions you may have.

componenttext: Maximum exposure in leasing, look, at this point, we're comfortable with the exposure we have, which, if you think about it, is probably about -- if you add PCLC plus about $2.2 billion or something, it's about second or 10% of the overall portfolio. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And also, I guess with the political discussions in Washington with regard to regulation, what's going to happen with the new bills. Is there anything in there that particularly worries you?
componenttext: And also, I guess with the political discussions in Washington with regard to regulation, what's going to happen with the new bills. Is there anything in there that particularly worries you?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's lots of things to worry us. And not just us, but I think most of the banking industry, frankly. One of course and primary one might be -- I guess there's two key issues. One is the consumer protection agency, the final status of that. In the
componenttext: Yes. There's lots of things to worry us. And not just us, but I think most of the banking industry, frankly. One of course and primary one might be -- I guess there's two key issues. One is the consumer protection agency, the final status of that. In the conversion of the Dodd bill, it was sort of to be housed in Treasury, but more like a tenant. We think that that's potentially very dangerous. We think that a prudential regulator should supervise the consumer financial protection agency in whatever form it ends up existing, I guess. So that's worry number one. Worry number two sort of equals worry number one, by the way, is the preemption issue. We think it's absolutely vital for the industry that we maintain preemption as it exists today, of federal law versus state laws. Otherwise, you're thinking about a potential disaster for companies operating across state lines like ourselves. So those are two issues that come to mind immediately as being totally key.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010

componenttext: Would that influence you as you're going about your due diligence on looking at acquisitions then looking hard...

componenttextpreview: No, because we're already a multi-state organization. So we'll have to live with whatever comes out of Washington. And hopefully, what comes out of it make sense rather than not. But we think the Dodd bill as it stands today, there are significant issues.
componenttext: No, because we're already a multi-state organization. So we'll have to live with whatever comes out of Washington. And hopefully, what comes out of it make sense rather than not. But we think the Dodd bill as it stands today, there are significant issues.

componenttext: It's pretty clear you've got an asset-sensitive balance sheet, and I guess the question that begs to be asked is has your view of interest rates change at all as it relates to when we might begin to see some of that asset sensitivity working its way into the P&L? Have you had any changes in terms of when you might think that rates begin to move higher? And if so, has there been a change in terms of how you're going to manage the balance sheet because of that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010

componenttext: Ken, unfortunately my crystal ball is probably as good as yours. I mean probably not very good. Frankly, we don't know. Consensus seems to be that maybe towards the end of the year, the Fed will change its language at least, or start raising rates. It depends a lot on the unemployment picture of course. If we start seeing changes there, then I believe the Fed is going to start modifying its stance. Otherwise, who knows. But I'm afraid I can't really help you there. Broadly speaking, it's within a year to a year and a half we think that it could change, but it could change sooner. It depends to what the Fed does and how you interprets economic conditions, I guess.

componenttext: No. That's a good question. The answer is no. I mean we've paid the price already. At this point, we're going to take the benefit when it happens. headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: And you spent a lot of the call talking about the M&A environment. At what juncture would you or what evidence then in the market would suggest that maybe the M&A opportunity has, in fact, passed? I mean today there's many different options. You've pointe
componenttext: And you spent a lot of the call talking about the M&A environment. At what juncture would you or what evidence then in the market would suggest that maybe the M&A opportunity has, in fact, passed? I mean today there's many different options. You've pointed out both in and out-of-market FDIC or healthy bank acquisitions. These are obviously dependent upon where we are in the cycle. What would you look out in the market and say, "Okay, there's really not a good opportunity at this stage because of where we are in the cycle or valuation, and maybe we need to address our excess capital position differently."

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 16, 2010
componenttextpreview: Listen, at this point, we simply feel that, in fact, the opportunities over the next year to two years are probably going to get better. Again, if you go back a year ago, when bank stock prices were really extremely depressed, transactions were, in fact,
componenttext: Listen, at this point, we simply feel that, in fact, the opportunities over the next year to two years are probably going to get better. Again, if you go back a year ago, when bank stock prices were really extremely depressed, transactions were, in fact, impossible because their multiples of tangible book were so low. Most banks simply weren't willing to sell. I think the recovery that we've seen recently in this sector is actually going to be helpful as we consider acquisitions. Because in part most likely now that those multiples have recovered, some banks are going to ask themselves a question, where does the next leg come from in terms of earnings, how are they grow earnings going forward, and wouldn't it take more sense to associate with a larger, stronger company such as ourselves. And hopefully, the answer is going to be yes in a number of cases.
