And then we have folks on the ground that will be relocating from different offices around Boston into the Boston office. We will undoubtedly add a few new people, but we don't think there's any kind of size or material impact there on comp with those programs.

componenttext: All right. I can't say that I have something that's clear in my mind what that will play out. But if you assume rates are where they are today, it will, again, depending on how much capital that we can get deployed and move the lower-yielding excess capital into something of higher return.

componenttext: We are.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about M&A and what you're seeing out there? Would you do expect a much more activity in 2011?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do, actually. Some of my opening remarks are trying to address our view of that. I think it's very, very clear to me from opportunities to have conversations with both and the content of those discussions that there's a lot of challenges in the bu
componenttext: Yes, we do, actually. Some of my opening remarks are trying to address our view of that. I think it's very, very clear to me from opportunities to have conversations with both and the content of those discussions that there's a lot of challenges in the business right now, and depending upon your relative position, it's very difficult to develop next year's plan. And so, I do see that greater willingness to have the conversation and to look at the option of selling versus continuing to do it alone. It seems to be there is more momentum there than even two quarters ago.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are some of the hangups possibly over pricing, or would it be the uncertainty within the regulatory environment? I guess, a part of it is that certain pricing for both sides are maybe on the part of the buyers, may be on what they think capital requiremen
componenttext: Are some of the hangups possibly over pricing, or would it be the uncertainty within the regulatory environment? I guess, a part of it is that certain pricing for both sides are maybe on the part of the buyers, may be on what they think capital requirements would be next year. Do these matters be resolved before the results lead to deals?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think people are kind of forming their views on both sides of those issues. I do agree that the buyers need to be very thoughtful about expectations, as well as evaluating their prospects for growing earnings on an independent path. So all of those dyna
componenttext: I think people are kind of forming their views on both sides of those issues. I do agree that the buyers need to be very thoughtful about expectations, as well as evaluating their prospects for growing earnings on an independent path. So all of those dynamics, I think, continue to and will always play into it, and the environment is difficult.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: One question is loan pricing. Are you seeing the pricing being more competitive these days or even bordering on irrational?
componenttext: One question is loan pricing. Are you seeing the pricing being more competitive these days or even bordering on irrational?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not at all. I think, I'll let Brian speak. I don't see any change in those spreads, dramatic change or any irrationality in entering things.
componenttext: Not at all. I think, I'll let Brian speak. I don't see any change in those spreads, dramatic change or any irrationality in entering things.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess other companies that we're talking about pricing in different tones. I think we had mixed messages. I guess.
componenttext: I guess other companies that we're talking about pricing in different tones. I think we had mixed messages. I guess.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would not say a rational. I think there has been some shrinkage in spreads, particularly in commercial real estate finance. And the days when you can get really attractive floors on floating rate loans are coming to an end. So I think we've gotten prett
componenttext: I would not say a rational. I think there has been some shrinkage in spreads, particularly in commercial real estate finance. And the days when you can get really attractive floors on floating rate loans are coming to an end. So I think we've gotten pretty far to one end of the pendulum in terms of the magnitude of spreads and it's come back to something more normal. But nowhere near irrational as it was say, three years ago.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well that kind of answers, I guess, but I'm still would love more color, Brian. On your comment on you made earlier just about feeling good sort of considering the economy, maybe, how is that feeling compared to where you sat last quarter, and maybe just
componenttext: Well that kind of answers, I guess, but I'm still would love more color, Brian. On your comment on you made earlier just about feeling good sort of considering the economy, maybe, how is that feeling compared to where you sat last quarter, and maybe just give me some specifics as to what's driving that specifically?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I feel about the same as I did in the last year. I don't think the economy is any better. We're closer to an election. Thank God, but we're in a unique position here. We've got really attractive markets opening up for us. We're going to be the big
componenttext: I think I feel about the same as I did in the last year. I don't think the economy is any better. We're closer to an election. Thank God, but we're in a unique position here. We've got really attractive markets opening up for us. We're going to be the biggest bank in Boston that has a home office in New England, and that's in the deal. And we're finally going to have troops on the ground in Long Island and closer to New York city, and that's a big deal. And we're just seeing all across our footprint opportunities for us. So I'm sort of excited about that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also, Collyn, sorry. It's Jack. If you look at the numbers, then you'll see that the commercial real estate and the C&I portfolios did have growth last quarter, this third quarter. And there was shrinkage in the portfolio and others that caused us to be f
componenttext: Also, Collyn, sorry. It's Jack. If you look at the numbers, then you'll see that the commercial real estate and the C&I portfolios did have growth last quarter, this third quarter. And there was shrinkage in the portfolio and others that caused us to be flat, but commercial group did have growth.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Jack, just following up on the buyback question. Can you remind us what the current authorization is outstanding?

componenttextpreview: $17 million.
componenttext: $17 million.

componenttext: 5% this year, yes.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you just sort of frame the buyback position? I guess, I'm just struggling with -- you've been consistent in your commentary when appropriate evaluating alternatives on the buyback. But I guess I just need to understand kind of  what goes on to those m
componenttext: Can you just sort of frame the buyback position? I guess, I'm just struggling with -- you've been consistent in your commentary when appropriate evaluating alternatives on the buyback. But I guess I just need to understand kind of  what goes on to those methodologies as you look at the buyback as a return alternative for this capital, especially nobody spoke to where your stock is today. But give a little bit more color, if you could, and why you still I guess -- I guess, I could ask you differently. Why are you not more rigid in saying, we will be buying bank our stock more aggressively assuming that the stock is at this level?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, because I think I don't want to come out and say, we will be doing it because we are continually discussing it with the management group and the board, and we don't have a clear definitive position that we're going to march forward with. There's a l
componenttext: Well, because I think I don't want to come out and say, we will be doing it because we are continually discussing it with the management group and the board, and we don't have a clear definitive position that we're going to march forward with. There's a lot of dynamics around that, as you know, and it's whether we have capital deployed in other ways, that might change our position in 30 days or whether we have a change in the stock price et cetera. That position could change. So that's why, I guess, I articulated the way I do. And I think it is something that we're going to evaluate on an ongoing basis. We've clearly demonstrated now that with the price at these levels, we believe it's an appropriate investment for us. And it certainly, you can interpret from the last two quarters that with the stock at these levels, we believe it's an appropriate way to deploy our capital and we're certainly not moving off of that view.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then extending that conversation or that question a little bit further, I mean, you guys are running a very, very tight balance sheet. And Paul, you had mentioned the asset-sensitivity position and strategy and philosophy hasn't changed that much. Wha
componenttext: And then extending that conversation or that question a little bit further, I mean, you guys are running a very, very tight balance sheet. And Paul, you had mentioned the asset-sensitivity position and strategy and philosophy hasn't changed that much. What do we assume by that? I mean is it, and maybe that ties into my question in terms of potential size of acquisition. As you look at the market, do you see kind of larger deals coming down the pipe? I mean, how do we think about or how do you guys think about kind of where you're going to get the best return on maybe a size of acquisition?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think just first of all, if we could get an appropriate an acquisition at a larger size, we deploy capital, more capital more quickly. And so, you can assume that, that would be more attractive to us. Let's say, given equivalent return views on a
componenttext: Well, I think just first of all, if we could get an appropriate an acquisition at a larger size, we deploy capital, more capital more quickly. And so, you can assume that, that would be more attractive to us. Let's say, given equivalent return views on a large and a small deal, for sure, and we are working hard to make some progress there. But we also kind of go back to our discussion over the last few quarters. We've clearly opened our lens, so to speak, and are looking at deals of $1 billion or up to say, $5 billion or larger. And if it's strategically valuable to us, if the franchise that we're looking at is very attractive because of location or other reasons, then we're going to look at it. So we don't want to be locked into just doing sizable deals and getting ourselves in a spot where we don't make progress, and we continue to have that view. So large is better and we're working on it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the other side, I'd like to respond with this. I mean theoretically, we could go raise $20 billion tomorrow and invest in mortgage-backed securities, but that would help our EPS in a very short-term. But it would really hurt us in the longer term to p
componenttext: And the other side, I'd like to respond with this. I mean theoretically, we could go raise $20 billion tomorrow and invest in mortgage-backed securities, but that would help our EPS in a very short-term. But it would really hurt us in the longer term to put out in some of the bulk with the 2% to 3% yield. And so that's why we sort of talked about we wanted to do things around the edges. We want to preserve the upside for what we believe will be a good capital deployment opportunities, opportunities to deleverage a little bit, but also, retain our profile so that we benefit when rates do go up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I respect the strategy that you've been employing. it's just, I guess, looking for maybe a little bit more nimbleness within that strategy, considering the environment that we sit in and the fear that this environment is prolonged for a longer period, and
componenttext: I respect the strategy that you've been employing. it's just, I guess, looking for maybe a little bit more nimbleness within that strategy, considering the environment that we sit in and the fear that this environment is prolonged for a longer period, and that's all. Just shifting gears quickly and I'll let somebody else hop in. Mortgage banking, can you just offer your views on mortgage banking? It's not been a huge business for you all. Is it something that you would to want to expand into? Is it that the infrastructure here may not be in place to handle the higher volumes and there were existing a lot of banks really posting some sizable growth this quarter, I just kind of want to get your philosophy on that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that we have been very committed to mortgage banking for a long time, and we continue to be and actually have high expectations there. We've had a strong retail origination force throughout our footprint for really quite some time. And w
componenttext: Well, I would say that we have been very committed to mortgage banking for a long time, and we continue to be and actually have high expectations there. We've had a strong retail origination force throughout our footprint for really quite some time. And we've also worked hard to develop our initiative to originate and take applications through the branches, and we continue to make progress there. And so, I think maybe, if you're looking at numbers that seems on a relative basis, smaller, it may be because while we're taking the gains in the secondary sales with the 30-year production, we're also starting to book more favorably structured deals for our balance sheet to stop that runoff. So we're very committed to having a strong mortgage banking operation, we're a huge retail franchise in New England and we've got a lot of customers looking to us to supply that product and we're very eager to help them.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Kelley representing Sterne Agee.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Matthew Kelley representing Sterne Agee.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: I just wanted to clarify on the securities purchases. You guys said you did $800 million in the  third quarter. What are you anticipating in the fourth quarter, just on the dollar month of purchases? Or is it done in terms of the large-scale purchases?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Toward the end, really what I said, Matthew, is we owned $800 million more in securities on average in the third quarter than we did in the second quarter. We did purchase at the end of the third quarter some additional securities with a shorter duration
componenttext: Toward the end, really what I said, Matthew, is we owned $800 million more in securities on average in the third quarter than we did in the second quarter. We did purchase at the end of the third quarter some additional securities with a shorter duration in the pass-throughs and that was within the bank. And so next quarter, we'll see probably an increase of about $400 million quarter-over-quarter.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of securities to asset ratio, I mean that'll get you kind of the mid-teens. Is that the way you want to be or?

componenttext: Jack, maybe I'll start, I wanted to follow-up on Collyn's capital deployment questions. I guess, generally speaking, the past few years, People's have been a story of sitting on excess capital waiting for the right deals. We know the board has changed leadership at the bank. It brought you to in accelerate this pace of capital deployment. So far, you've done a good job, a couple of deals, bought back some stock. Curious as when you look at 2011, can you help us think about your view or the Board's view on what is an acceptable pace of capital deployment? And if deals do not materialize, is there a minimum amount of capital that you're planning to use via share buyback or other tools?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think basically, there is no specific timeframe that the board has laid out in front of me or the management group, as it relates to capital deployment pace. I think whenever, I think of this subject, I think of our investors and the board message, whic
componenttext: I think basically, there is no specific timeframe that the board has laid out in front of me or the management group, as it relates to capital deployment pace. I think whenever, I think of this subject, I think of our investors and the board message, which is the last thing we want to do is allow the deal and do something just to force something for the wrong reason, and that always remains in the front of all of our minds. So I think that's kind of an important starting point. As it relates to whether deals materialize in a reasonable timeframe, if they don't, and will we considered changes in our posture to do buybacks or special dividend or other alternatives, the answer is absolutely, yes. And when I talk about us regularly re-examining our posture and alternatives, those conversations certainly do come up. But we definitely remain primarily focused on deploying the capital through acquisitions, and realizing on our strategic plan to deploy the capital, and then grow the franchise and realize on that capital in that fashion.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for today's call. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Burner, our Chief Financial Officer; and other members of our management team are gathered for the call.Before we get started, please r
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for today's call. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Burner, our Chief Financial Officer; and other members of our management team are gathered for the call.
Before we get started, please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of our presentation, which is posted on our website, www.peoples.com under Investor Relations. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today. As you know, today, we'll be reviewing our earnings for the third quarter, and we look forward to your questions after our comments are complete. Before we go through the slid
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today. As you know, today, we'll be reviewing our earnings for the third quarter, and we look forward to your questions after our comments are complete. 
Before we go through the slides, I'd like to share with you some of my perspective on our two primary strategic objectives: First, to optimize the existing business, and second, to sufficiently deploy our excess capital. With regard to optimizing our business, we believe we have a more robust opportunity set relative to many in the industry. We continue to work towards additional revenue synergies made available from completed acquisitions over the last several years. We have active initiatives currently underway relative to these opportunities in all of our business lines. Certainly, the acquisitions of Bank of Smithtown and RiverBank and our branch openings in Boston, all of which we expect to close by year end, will create additional opportunity to enhance revenue going forward. 
On the capital deployment front, we have an organized acquisition plan and a targeted effort is underway. Our management team has continued to build relationships within the industry, which we believe will lead to attractive combinations. The challenge, of course, as always, relates to differing views on price. Today, we feel sellers are becoming more realistic with respect to price as a result of challenges facing the industry. The value of the synergies from consolidation relative to the value available following an independent path should add momentum to these conversations. 
On Slide 3, we provide an overview of our third quarter results. Operating net income for the quarter was $27.7 million or $0.08 per share, excluding $5.3 million or $0.01 per share for onetime costs related to the system conversion and mergers. Net interest margin expanded by five basis points from 3.68% in the second quarter to 3.73% in the third quarter as a result of higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. 
Asset quality remained strong. However, net charge-offs grew to 57 basis points versus 46 basis points in the prior quarter. As we discussed in the press release, two construction projects represent 45% of the quarter's net charge-offs. These credits did have specific reserves against them. Given the increase in NPAs and the climate of persistently high unemployment and weak economics, we felt it was prudent to cover our net charge-offs. Importantly, we continue to feel comfortable that our asset quality metrics will remain at low levels. 
Finally, while growth in commercial banking portfolio was offset by declines in our residential mortgage and consumer lending, we are pleased by our strong pipeline for commercial and residential mortgages as we move into the fourth quarter. Slide 4 addresses our current initiatives. 
Our system conversion is complete, and we are now operating a single scalable platform. The rebranding of our branches in the Vermont, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Maine markets is also effectively complete. Our acquisitions of Smithtown Bancorp and LSB Corp. are both expected to close next month, providing, of course, that all the necessary shareholder and regulatory approvals take place. 
Additionally, we are set to open our Boston branches in the Prudential Center and on Milk Street before year end. 
During the third quarter, we repurchased $25 million of our common stock, equal to 1.9 million shares at an average price of $13.29. This was limited because of the stock component of our pending Bank of Smithtown transaction. The repurchase program was effected through open market purchases. We will continue to evaluate the returns available to us via the share repurchases relative to the rest of our capital deployment opportunities. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Paul to provide you with details on the quarter. Paul?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack, and good morning to you all. As Jack mentioned, our overall debt interest margin expanded to 3.73%, up five basis points from the second quarter, driven by higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. In the third quarter, we had $80
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack, and good morning to you all. As Jack mentioned, our overall debt interest margin expanded to 3.73%, up five basis points from the second quarter, driven by higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. In the third quarter, we had $800 million more in securities on average than in the second quarter. 
We made investments of $500 million in callable agencies at the holding company and an additional $300 million of 15-year agency mortgage-backed pass-throughs at the bank. The duration of the securities portfolio declined slightly to 2.36 years. 
Despite the investments, we remained highly asset-sensitive such that earnings will increase by $40 million annually for every 100 basis point increase in the fed funds rate. 
Moving on to Slide 6. NPAs increased to 2.18% from 2.01% of loans in REO. Compared to the second quarter average of our peer group in Top 50 banks, however, our ratio is less than half their levels. We continue to feel comfortable with our asset quality in the current environment. 
On Slide 7, in the Commercial and Equipment Financing segment, while NPLs increased 10 basis points, net charge-offs in the Commercial and Equipment Financing segment dropped to 37 basis points annualized for the quarter from 92 basis points last quarter. This equates to $4.7 million in the third quarter versus $11.7 million in the second quarter for a $7 million decline. 
This is actually a good moment to reflect on the lumpiness we discussed last quarter. Given our low level of charge-offs as a starting point, a single creditor too can cause the annualized charge-offs in any one quarter to move meaningfully. Last quarter, that movement in this category was up. And this quarter in this category, the movement was down. 
Page 13 of the press release itemizes charge-off levels by loan category. And you'll notice that within the Equipment Finance subsegment, charge-offs declined to $1.6 million this quarter from $3.7 million in the second quarter. 
On Slide 8, you can see a breakout of our commercial real estate credit performance. And NPAs were 1.55%, compared to 1.23% in the second quarter, while NCOs rose to 98 basis points from 35 basis points as a result of the two construction projects. This equates to $13.5 million in the third quarter versus $4.8 million in the second quarter for an $8.7 million increase. It's worth noting that fully 99% of the commercial real estate charge-offs in this quarter were construction related. And in fact, year-to-date, 94% of commercial real estate charge-offs have been in construction. Our portfolio remains well diversified, and we believe we'll continue to see strong portfolio growth opportunities. 
Slide 9 illustrates our residential loan credit performance. As you can see, our NPLs have increased to 3.67%. Unfortunately, nonperforming residential mortgage resolution continues to take much longer than previously as a result of a much slower foreclosure process in the courts. 
Our loss content has been low, as you can see in the bottom chart, and we believe itll continue to be at low levels because we have low loan to value at originations, and because approximately 85% of our nonperforming loans have current loan to values of less than 90%. We feel good about the residential mortgage pipeline of originations. 
On Slide 10, you can see our Home Equity nonperforming loans continue at low levels comparable to those in the second quarter. Our net charge-offs were up a bit at 26 basis points, but still significantly below industry levels. Utilization rates remain stable at 49%.  We continue to feel the Home Equity offering is an important part of our retail customer relationships. 
Slide 11 reflects our charge-off experience over the past few years. We believe that the range over the last three to four quarters is consistent with the current weak economic environment. And year-to-date, our charge-offs have averaged 43 basis points. 
Slide 12 speaks to our competitive advantage relative to the industry with regard to asset quality and capital. And with that, I'll now hand it back to Jack to wrap it up before we open it up for your questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. In summary on Slide 13, we believe we continue to offer a compelling investment opportunity. We operate from a position of competitive strength and intend to enhance this position by continuing to focus on improving our operating performance
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. In summary on Slide 13, we believe we continue to offer a compelling investment opportunity. We operate from a position of competitive strength and intend to enhance this position by continuing to focus on improving our operating performance. We'll continue to pursue capital deployment through well-priced acquisitions, while maintaining a strong dividend and evaluating the returns available from share repurchases.  Further, given the multiyear deleveraging process and the increased regulatory pressures in the sector, we believe potential partners are becoming more interested in combination discussions. 
Finally, we are significantly more asset-sensitive than our peers. So when rates finally do rise, we will have a disproportionate positive impact on our interest income. This concludes our presentation, and now we'll be happy to answer any questions you might have.

componenttext: Well, I guess, the first part of the question, as we look forward and think about the impact of the acquisitions on our margin, with the purchase accounting, that transition should be fairly neutral. And based on our overall view of existing portfolio, cost of funds, et cetera, we're feeling pretty good about being able to maintain in this range. And I'll let Paul address the investment portfolio. As you can tell, we've been working at trying to make good progress there, and we'll continue to work it while we avoid going too far out on the duration.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I guess, what I'd add, Mark, is our overall assets, despite the investing that we've done, our overall asset sensitivity has really remained pretty constant. As we look forward and look at sort of legacy business, putting aside the acquisitions for a
componenttext: Yes, I guess, what I'd add, Mark, is our overall assets, despite the investing that we've done, our overall asset sensitivity has really remained pretty constant. As we look forward and look at sort of legacy business, putting aside the acquisitions for a moment, we actually see a moderate upward bias with regard to the net interest margin. And I would say, it's really sort of moderate. So I think, as Jack said, we feel very good about the maintenance there. And we want to keep our powder dry with regard to asset sensitivity so that we do benefit. We felt the pain of lower earnings through the lower rate cycle, and we look forward to earnings growing as rates eventually increase. In the interim, with our pricing actions, we think we can continue to deliver the net interest margin we have, and seek a little bit of improvement.

componenttext: Well, this gets us into this -- what we realized this quarter was given the fact that we did have a couple of credits that we needed to recognize and that NPAs increased, we felt it was the right move. I would expect, and our comments about expecting asset quality to remain at lower levels would mean that we'll find the right balance there as we go forward, but I wouldn't want to predict that we'll absolutely match or not in future quarters.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian Dreyer. I'm not going to give you specific numbers, because we don't disclose those. But I will give you some color. First, and you have to look at our individual businesses, because things are different depending upon which business you're talking
componenttext: Brian Dreyer. I'm not going to give you specific numbers, because we don't disclose those. But I will give you some color. First, and you have to look at our individual businesses, because things are different depending upon which business you're talking about. But our biggest business is our Commercial Real Estate Finance business, and that's been strong, and it remains strong, and the pipelines are very good. It's interesting, almost everything is a refinance opportunity. Many, many of those, if not most, are credit-grade tenants. There's almost no new construction, and the vast majority of the deals are in office and retail. It's across the footprint, but we have definite concentrations in Fairfield County, and inside 128 in the Boston market, and also in New York and New Jersey. As far as C&I is concerned, I would say, that's reasonably strong. Again, concentrating in Connecticut, some in New York, particularly in Brooklyn and Westchester. Although we just committed and we're in the process of closing a $50 million deal, that's 5-0, in Vermont, we'll be the agent. That's probably the biggest deal in Vermont this year and maybe in a couple of years. I'm not really sure. The problem in C&I is our utilization rates and our lines of credit are running about 45%, and that's about flat from last year. We've really seen no increase. And whereas the normal rate in our portfolios generally is around 65%. So there's a lot of demand that is just not there right now compared to what our commitments are. In terms of what you're going to see in the future, we are about to deploy new C&I teams inside 128 as soon as those Boston branches open, and we have high expectations for what they might be able to achieve. And we're also ready to put teams on the ground as soon as the Smithtown acquisition closes, to really start calling aggressively in Long Island and into New York City. Now as far as the Equipment Finance businesses are concerned, the PCLC business is reasonably strong. And its mostly in the direct channel, direct sales channel, and it's across the board in most of our business lines. It's not what it's been in past years, but I still would say reasonably strong. As opposed to Financial Federal, which has now just changed its name to People's United Equipment Finance, the business is very slow there. There's a big construction concentration, and I don't think it's a surprise to anybody that the construction industry is very slow. So there just aren't a lot of new business opportunities and there's still shrinkage in that portfolio. So as we go forward, we're seeing, and we're going to see, decent increases, modest increases in some portfolios, stronger increases in others. But overall, I feel pretty good, considering the economy that we're all facing.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to add to and kind of finish the second part of the equation, we've got a couple of million dollar pipeline in the residential side. And as you know, that's what we see going into the portfolio. I think this quarter, we had the goal of stemming the t
componenttext: Just to add to and kind of finish the second part of the equation, we've got a couple of million dollar pipeline in the residential side. And as you know, that's what we see going into the portfolio. I think this quarter, we had the goal of stemming the tide on the shrinkage in the residential portfolio, and our group teams have been working hard to do that. And while we had a slight decline this quarter, we've really turned the corner, we believe. And we're looking at several hundred million dollars closing as we move forward.

componenttext: I was hoping you could talk just a little bit about buybacks. First, maybe just remind all of us what the restrictions are that you currently have right now, because obviously, you can buy back some shares but not a lot, and what are your plans after Smithtown closes? And then how do you view buybacks broadly speaking in relation to the fact that you may actually use shares at some point, or maybe you won't, to actually do an acquisition?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Paul. With regard to the restrictions, we actually have been blocked out for some time now because we're using our stock as a portion of the consideration for the Smithtown acquisition. And we will remain blocked out until after the Sharehold
componenttext: Ken, this is Paul. With regard to the restrictions, we actually have been blocked out for some time now because we're using our stock as a portion of the consideration for the Smithtown acquisition. And we will remain blocked out until after the Shareholders' Meeting, which is November 19th or 20th. So we do have to remain out of the market until then, and then could resume. With regard to our overall posture, I'll pass it back to you, Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would suggest to all of you that the posture that we've portrayed in the last several quarters remains intact, if you will, with shares value dropping to levels where we believe it's attractive versus our future earnings expectations and valuation, then
componenttext: I would suggest to all of you that the posture that we've portrayed in the last several quarters remains intact, if you will, with shares value dropping to levels where we believe it's attractive versus our future earnings expectations and valuation, then we'll move into the market and continue to buy under the approved plan. We are talking about it regularly, internally and with the board, and re-evaluating the size of our repurchase plan and also our activity, and it's really an ongoing process. That's about it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just a related question, when you think about the cash that you're putting into agencies, I understand it's fairly short duration. Maybe talk about your ability to pull that out if you do find a sizable acquisition. Are those securities, I guess, mo
componenttext: Maybe just a related question, when you think about the cash that you're putting into agencies, I understand it's fairly short duration. Maybe talk about your ability to pull that out if you do find a sizable acquisition. Are those securities, I guess, monetizable, in a very short manner without taking any losses?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, they are. Unfortunately, as rates have continued downward, actually, we take a gain. But I guess the philosophy is we're just putting a portion of the excess capital that's with the holding company, investing a term or keeping a portion in cash. And
componenttext: Well, they are. Unfortunately, as rates have continued downward, actually, we take a gain. But I guess the philosophy is we're just putting a portion of the excess capital that's with the holding company, investing a term or keeping a portion in cash. And we're keeping the durations such that even, I mean, as with the River and Smithtown acquisition, there's unfortunately, a few-month period between deal announcement and the closing. But I guess the way we look at it is, is if the market moved around a little and we wanted the $500 million to fund an acquisition a little earlier, and we had to take $0.5 million, $1 million charge, that would really be de minimis. Meanwhile, we don't think we'll be using it. So we prefer to get income back up. Clearly, it's not money we put into 30-year mortgages. Because as long as we're keeping it in, relatively short term and as part of our cash flow forecast.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Damon DelMonte representing KBW.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Damon DelMonte representing KBW.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: With respect to asset quality, NPLs do continue to rise. They have been over the last four or five quarters, albeit you're still at relatively lower rates compared to some of your larger peers throughout the region and the country. But can you give us any
componenttext: With respect to asset quality, NPLs do continue to rise. They have been over the last four or five quarters, albeit you're still at relatively lower rates compared to some of your larger peers throughout the region and the country. But can you give us any sense of, are you comfortable with reaching a cresting level anytime soon?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I go back to my kind of opening remarks. We're very comfortable that our asset quality metrics are going to remain at low levels. And I go back to our track record and our confidence in our underwriting, and actually also, our confidence in our cust
componenttext: Well, I go back to my kind of opening remarks. We're very comfortable that our asset quality metrics are going to remain at low levels. And I go back to our track record and our confidence in our underwriting, and actually also, our confidence in our customers. We're very pleased with how our customers have navigated through this economic downturn and the length of it, and we remain very solidly comfortable with both aspects of that. That said, you get to this issue of predicting levels, and the way we operate is to kind of deal with reality and what's in front of us at the time. So given our track record and given our current view, we feel very strongly that were in a, and will continue to be, in a solid place. But what happens in the economy and the environment is, to me, there remains a lot of uncertainty and we have to wait and see what happens.

componenttext: So my recollection, generally, as we look at that increase, it really came in a very granular way. I think the largest addition was $2 million. And then below that there were some, I'm thinking of the C&I. So in the C&I, the largest was $2 million and then there was a lot of other smaller loans, roughly $15 million or so that were added. And the commercial real estate, we did have an $8 million deal that was added and then three others that were a variety of projects in kind of $2 million to $3 million range.

componenttext: This is Jack. I just want to add to that something, because I'm very encouraged by it. We not only have the movement of some of the folks that Brian described, but if you think about our operation in Portsmouth, New Hampshire, many of the folks and those officers have been active in calling into Boston and within 128. And the Riverbank folks also, very active along the 128 corridor. So we really have a group of experienced people on the ground and familiar with the territory and we really feel good about our momentum there.

componenttext: Yes, we've talked about that in the past, and we have moved through a number of stages through the project, if you will, in the last year or two to address our expense savings that we expected. We talked about savings in the range on an annualized operating basis of $10 million, and we continue to believe that we will achieve those goals.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Should we expect the savings to begin immediately? Or is that something thats sort of...
componenttext: Should we expect the savings to begin immediately? Or is that something thats sort of...

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, its -- actually, some of it begin to impact following the first quarter and the event in Connecticut in February, and then some kicked in after the July event, Northern New England, and we continue to work on settling the conversion and getting t
componenttext: Well, its -- actually, some of it begin to impact following the first quarter and the event in Connecticut in February, and then some kicked in after the July event, Northern New England, and we continue to work on settling the conversion and getting things smoothed out and adjusting our overhead and enjoying a different cost structure in the services that we get related to the core. And all of that is and will continue to be phasing in through the end of the year.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just turning to the efficiency ratio, it's pretty high compared to similar-sized institutions. Is there any sort of initiatives or plans to improve operating leverage?
componenttext: Just turning to the efficiency ratio, it's pretty high compared to similar-sized institutions. Is there any sort of initiatives or plans to improve operating leverage?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'd say two things there. First, it is very high compared to peers, and we recognize that. If you kind of either look at giving the excess capital a fair normalized rate, if you will, of return, and you put that revenue into the equation, you'd see
componenttext: Well, I'd say two things there. First, it is very high compared to peers, and we recognize that. If you kind of either look at giving the excess capital a fair normalized rate, if you will, of return, and you put that revenue into the equation, you'd see that we're kind of in line, I would call it, with peers. I think we calculate it generally, in the high 50s. But that said, we recognize also that initiatives around expense savings and being an efficiently run company is important. And things like the core conversion initiative and moving through that are critical, and we're constantly working on initiatives to improve our operating performance. And that includes becoming more efficient and getting an efficiency level that we'll be pleased with, and it will be somewhere in that mid-50 range.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any timing on that?
componenttext: Any timing on that?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it reallyll depend a lot on capital deployment.
componenttext: Well, it reallyll depend a lot on capital deployment.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, actually -- it's Paul. Let me just sort of add. If we do a pro forma today, given the asset sensitivity I mentioned, each 1% increase in the Fed Funds rate adding $40 million, if we just sort of do a fast forward to a 5% Fed Funds rate with our exa
componenttext: Chris, actually -- it's Paul. Let me just sort of add. If we do a pro forma today, given the asset sensitivity I mentioned, each 1% increase in the Fed Funds rate adding $40 million, if we just sort of do a fast forward to a 5% Fed Funds rate with our exact same balance sheet, that's where our efficiency ratio would actually drop to -- because the revenue increase associated with a 5% Fed Funds rate, the efficiency ratio would drop to the 58% level. So the very fact that we have been so asset sensitive in this climbing rate environment is we felt the pain of that revenue loss. It's actually unfortunately caused our efficiency to go up year-over-year.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Well, there's a lot of specific dynamics in that, but I think as you could hear Brian describing, we've got some long-term employees from various markets where we are operating moving in to Boston. And then we have folks on the ground that will be relocating from different offices around Boston into the Boston office. We will undoubtedly add a few new people, but we don't think there's any kind of a size or material impact there on comp with those programs.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I can't say that I have something that's clear in my mind what that will play out. But if you assume rates are where they are today, it will, again, depend on how much capital that we can get deployed and move the lower-yielding excess capital into
componenttext: Well, I can't say that I have something that's clear in my mind what that will play out. But if you assume rates are where they are today, it will, again, depend on how much capital that we can get deployed and move the lower-yielding excess capital into something at higher return.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: And then maybe last question I'll ask has to do with loans. I know you talked about the pipeline. It sounds like the trends are encouraging there. But of course, pay downs are a headwind as well. Given where the pipelines are, are you optimistic to see net loan growth in the fourth quarter?

componenttext: We are.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about M&A and what you're seeing out there? Would you do expect a much more activity in 2011?
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about M&A and what you're seeing out there? Would you do expect a much more activity in 2011?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do, actually. Some of my opening remarks were trying to address our view of that. I think it's very, very clear to me from opportunities to have conversations with folks and the content of those discussions that there is a lot of challenges in the
componenttext: Yes, we do, actually. Some of my opening remarks were trying to address our view of that. I think it's very, very clear to me from opportunities to have conversations with folks and the content of those discussions that there is a lot of challenges in the business right now, and depending on your relative position, it's very difficult to develop next year's plan. And so, I do see that greater willingness to have the conversation and to look at the option of selling versus continuing to go it alone. It seems to me theres more momentum there than even two quarters ago.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are some of the hang-ups possibly over pricing? Or would it be uncertainty with the regulatory environment? I guess, a part of it is the uncertainty on pricing for both sides, maybe on the part of the buyers, maybe on what like, say, capital requirements
componenttext: Are some of the hang-ups possibly over pricing? Or would it be uncertainty with the regulatory environment? I guess, a part of it is the uncertainty on pricing for both sides, maybe on the part of the buyers, maybe on what like, say, capital requirements will be next year. Do these matters have to solved before theres a flood in deals?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think people are kind of forming their views on both sides of those issues. I do agree that the buyers need to be very thoughtful about expectations, as well as the sellers evaluating their prospects for growing earnings on an independent path. So all o
componenttext: I think people are kind of forming their views on both sides of those issues. I do agree that the buyers need to be very thoughtful about expectations, as well as the sellers evaluating their prospects for growing earnings on an independent path. So all of those dynamics, I think, continue to and will always play into it, and the environment is difficult.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And finally, one question is loan pricing. Are you seeing the pricing being more competitive these days or even bordering on irrational?
componenttext: And finally, one question is loan pricing. Are you seeing the pricing being more competitive these days or even bordering on irrational?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not at all. I think, I'll let Brian speak. I don't see any change in spreads, dramatic change or any irrationality entering things.
componenttext: Not at all. I think, I'll let Brian speak. I don't see any change in spreads, dramatic change or any irrationality entering things.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess other companies were talking about pricing in different tones. So Im getting mixed messages, I guess.
componenttext: I guess other companies were talking about pricing in different tones. So Im getting mixed messages, I guess.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure.  Ill let Brian speak to it.
componenttext: Sure.  Ill let Brian speak to it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would not say irrational. I think there has been some shrinkage in spreads, particularly in commercial real estate finance. And the days when you could get really attractive floors on floating rate loans are coming to an end. So I think we've gotten pre
componenttext: I would not say irrational. I think there has been some shrinkage in spreads, particularly in commercial real estate finance. And the days when you could get really attractive floors on floating rate loans are coming to an end. So I think we've gotten pretty far to one end of the pendulum in terms of the magnitude of spreads, and it's come back to something more normal, but nowhere near irrational as it was say, three years ago.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Well, that kind of answers, I guess, but I still would love more color, Brian. On your comment that you made earlier just about feeling good, sort of considering the economy, maybe, how is that feeling compared to where you sat last quarter, and maybe just give me some specifics as to what's driving that specifically?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think I feel about the same as I did in the last quarter. I don't think the economy is any better. We're closer to an election, thank God, but we're in a unique position here. We've got really attractive markets opening up for us. We're going to be the
componenttext: I think I feel about the same as I did in the last quarter. I don't think the economy is any better. We're closer to an election, thank God, but we're in a unique position here. We've got really attractive markets opening up for us. We're going to be the biggest bank calling in Boston that has a home office in New England, and that's a big deal. And we're finally going to have troops on the ground in Long Island and closer to New York City, and that's a big deal. And we're just seeing all across our footprint opportunities for us. So I'm sort of excited about that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Also, Collyn, sorry. It's Jack. If you look at the numbers, I think you'll see that the commercial real estate and the C&I portfolios did have growth last quarter, this third quarter. And there was shrinkage in the Sig [ph] portfolio and others that cause
componenttext: Also, Collyn, sorry. It's Jack. If you look at the numbers, I think you'll see that the commercial real estate and the C&I portfolios did have growth last quarter, this third quarter. And there was shrinkage in the Sig [ph] portfolio and others that caused us to be flat, but commercial groups did have growth.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Can you just sort of frame the buyback position? I guess, I'm just struggling with -- you've been consistent in your commentary when appropriate evaluating alternatives on the buyback. But I guess I just, I need to understand kind of what goes into those methodologies as you look at the buyback as a return alternative for this capital, especially -- and nobody spoke essentially to where your stock is today. But just give a little bit more color, if you could, on why you still arent -- I guess I should -- I guess I could ask it differently. Why are you not more rigid in saying, we will be buying back our stock more aggressively, assuming that the stock is at this level?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, because I think I don't want to come out and say, we will be doing it because we are continually discussing it with the management group and the board, and we don't have a clear definitive position that we're going to march forward with. There's a l
componenttext: Well, because I think I don't want to come out and say, we will be doing it because we are continually discussing it with the management group and the board, and we don't have a clear definitive position that we're going to march forward with. There's a lot of dynamics around that, as you know, and if, whether we have capital deployed in other ways, that might change our position in 30 days or whether we have a change in the stock price, et cetera, that position could change. So that's why, I guess, I articulate it the way I do. And I think it is something that we are going to evaluate on an ongoing basis. We've clearly demonstrated now that with the price at these levels, we believe it's an appropriate investment for us. And it certainly, you can interpret from the last two quarters that with the stock at these levels, we believe it's an appropriate action, a way to deploy the capital, and we're certainly not moving off of that view.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010

componenttext: Offering the average cost, we obviously know where your price point is.  But I was just kind of thinking about size. And then extending that conversation or that question a little bit further, I mean, you guys are running a very, very tight balance sheet. And Paul, you had mentioned the asset-sensitivity position and strategy, and philosophy hasn't changed that much. What do we assume by that? I mean is it, and maybe that ties into my question in terms of potential size of acquisition. As you look at the market, do you see kind of larger deals coming down the pipe? I mean, how do we think about or how do you guys think about kind of where you're going to get the best return on maybe a size of acquisition?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, I mean, just first of all, if we could get an appropriate, an acquisition at a larger size, wed deploy capital, more capital more quickly. And so, you can assume that, that would be more attractive to us. Let's say, given equivalent retu
componenttext: Well, I think, I mean, just first of all, if we could get an appropriate, an acquisition at a larger size, wed deploy capital, more capital more quickly. And so, you can assume that, that would be more attractive to us. Let's say, given equivalent return views on a large and a small deal, for sure, and we are working hard to make some progress there. But we also kind of go back to our discussion over the last few quarters. We've clearly opened our lens, so to speak, and are looking at deals of $1 billion or up to say, $5 billion or larger. And if it's strategically valuable to us, if the franchise that we're looking at is very attractive because of location or other reasons, then we're going to look at it. So we don't want to be locked into just doing sizable deals and getting ourselves in a spot where we don't make progress, and we continue to have that view. So large is better, and we're working at it.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Collyn, I think the other side, which I'd like to respond with this. I mean, theoretically, we could go raise $20 billion tomorrow and invest in mortgage-backed securities, and that would help our EPS in the very short-term. But it would really hurt u
componenttext: And Collyn, I think the other side, which I'd like to respond with this. I mean, theoretically, we could go raise $20 billion tomorrow and invest in mortgage-backed securities, and that would help our EPS in the very short-term. But it would really hurt us in the longer term to put assets on the book with a 2% to 3% yield. And so that's why we sort of talk about we wanted to do things around the edges. We want to preserve the upside for what we believe will be good capital deployment opportunities, opportunities to deleverage a little bit, but also, retain our profile so that we benefit when rates do go up.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I respect the strategy that you've been employing. It's just, I guess, looking for maybe a little bit more nimbleness within that strategy, considering the environment that we sit in and the fear that this environment is prolonged for a longer period, and
componenttext: I respect the strategy that you've been employing. It's just, I guess, looking for maybe a little bit more nimbleness within that strategy, considering the environment that we sit in and the fear that this environment is prolonged for a longer period, and that's all. Just shifting gears quickly, and I'll let somebody else hop in. Mortgage banking, can you just offer your views on mortgage banking? It's not been a huge business for you all. Is it something that you would to want to expand into? Is it that the infrastructure here may not in place to handle the higher volumes? I mean, were just seeing a lot of banks really posting some sizable growth this quarter. I just kind of want to get your philosophy on that.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say that we have been very committed to mortgage banking for a long time, and we continue to be and actually have high expectations there. We've had a strong retail origination force throughout our footprint for really quite some time. And w
componenttext: Well, I would say that we have been very committed to mortgage banking for a long time, and we continue to be and actually have high expectations there. We've had a strong retail origination force throughout our footprint for really quite some time. And we've also worked hard to develop our initiative to originate, take applications through the branches, and we continue to make progress there. And so I think maybe, if you're looking at numbers that seem on a relative basis, smaller, it may be because while we're taking the gains on the secondary sales with the 30-year production, we're also starting to book more favorably structured deals for our balance sheet to stop that runoff. So we're very committed to having a strong mortgage banking operation, we're a huge retail franchise in New England, and we've got a lot of customers looking to us to supply that product, and we're very eager to help them.

componenttext: Jack, maybe I'll start, I wanted to follow up on Collyn's capital deployment questions. I guess, generally speaking, the past few years, People's has been a story of sitting on excess capital waiting for the right deals. We know the board has changed leadership at the bank, right, brought you to in accelerate this pace of capital deployment. So far, you've done a good job, couple of deals, bought back some stock. Curious as when you look at 2011, can you help us think about your view as well as maybe the Board's view on what is an acceptable pace of capital deployment? And if deals do not materialize, is there a minimum amount of capital that you're planning to use via share buyback or other tools?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I think basically, there is no specific time frame that the board has laid out in front of me or the management group, as it relates to the capital deployment pace. I think whenever I think of this subject, I think of our investors and the board messag
componenttext: So I think basically, there is no specific time frame that the board has laid out in front of me or the management group, as it relates to the capital deployment pace. I think whenever I think of this subject, I think of our investors and the board message, which is the last thing we want to do is a lousy the deal and do something just to force something for the wrong reason, and that always remains in the front of all of our minds. So I think that's kind of an important starting point. As it relates to whether deals materialize in a reasonable time frame, if they don't, and will we considered changes in our posture to buybacks or special dividend or other alternatives, the answer is absolutely yes. And when I talk about us regularly re-examining our posture and our alternatives there, those conversations certainly do come up. But we definitely remain primarily focused on deploying the capital through acquisitions and realizing on our strategic plan to deploy the capital and grow the franchise and realize on that capital in that fashion.

componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the People's United Financial Incorporated Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Katina, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to your host for today's call, Mr. Peter Goulding, Vice President of Investor Relations for People's United Financial Inc. Please proceed, sir.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us for today's call. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Burner, our Chief Financial Officer; and other members of our management team are gathered for the call.Before we get started, please r
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us for today's call. Jack Barnes, President and Chief Executive Officer; Paul Burner, our Chief Financial Officer; and other members of our management team are gathered for the call.
Before we get started, please remember to refer to our forward-looking statements on Slide 1 of our presentation, which is posted on our website, www.peoples.com under Investor Relations. With that, I'll turn the call over to Jack.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today. As you know, today, we'll be reviewing our earnings for the third quarter, and we look forward to your questions after our comments are complete. Before we go through the slid
componenttext:
Thank you, Peter. Good morning, everyone. And thank you for joining us today. As you know, today, we'll be reviewing our earnings for the third quarter, and we look forward to your questions after our comments are complete. 
Before we go through the slides, I'd like to share with you some of my perspective on our two primary strategic objectives: First, to optimize the existing business, and second, to sufficiently deploy our excess capital. With regard to optimizing our business, we believe we have a more robust opportunity set relative to many in the industry. We continue to work towards additional revenue synergies made available from completed acquisitions over the last several years. We have active initiatives currently underway relative to these opportunities in all of our business lines. Certainly, the acquisitions of Bank of Smithtown and RiverBank and our branch openings in Boston, all of which we expect to close by year end, will create additional opportunity to enhance revenue going forward. 
On the capital deployment front, we have an organized acquisition plan and a targeted effort is underway. Our management team has continued to build relationships within the industry, which we believe will lead to attractive combinations. The challenge, of course, as always, relates to differing views on price. Today, we feel sellers are becoming more realistic with respect to price as a result of challenges facing the industry. The value of the synergies from consolidation relative to the value available following an independent path should add momentum to these conversations. 
On Slide 3, we provide an overview of our third quarter results. Operating net income for the quarter was $27.7 million or $0.08 per share, excluding $5.3 million or $0.01 per share for onetime costs related to the system conversion and mergers. Net interest margin expanded by five basis points from 3.68% in the second quarter to 3.73% in the third quarter as a result of higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. 
Asset quality remained strong. However, net charge-offs grew to 57 basis points versus 46 basis points in the prior quarter. As we discussed in the press release, two construction projects represent 45% of the quarter's net charge-offs. These credits did have specific reserves against them. Given the increase in NPAs and the climate of persistently high unemployment and weak economics, we felt it was prudent to cover our net charge-offs. Importantly, we continue to feel comfortable that our asset quality metrics will remain at low levels. 
Finally, while growth in commercial banking portfolio was offset by declines in our residential mortgage and consumer lending, we are pleased by our strong pipeline for commercial and residential mortgages as we move into the fourth quarter. Slide 4 addresses our current initiatives. 
Our system conversion is complete, and we are now operating a single scalable platform. The rebranding of our branches in the Vermont, New Hampshire, Massachusetts and Maine markets is also effectively complete. Our acquisitions of Smithtown Bancorp and LSB Corp. are both expected to close next month, providing, of course, that all the necessary shareholder and regulatory approvals take place. 
Additionally, we are set to open our Boston branches in the Prudential Center and on Milk Street before year end. 
During the third quarter, we repurchased $25 million of our common stock, equal to 1.9 million shares at an average price of $13.29. This was limited because of the stock component of our pending Bank of Smithtown transaction. The repurchase program was effected through open market purchases. We will continue to evaluate the returns available to us via the share repurchases relative to the rest of our capital deployment opportunities. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Paul to provide you with details on the quarter. Paul?

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jack, and good morning to you all. As Jack mentioned, our overall debt interest margin expanded to 3.73%, up five basis points from the second quarter, driven by higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. In the third quarter, we had $80
componenttext:
Thank you, Jack, and good morning to you all. As Jack mentioned, our overall debt interest margin expanded to 3.73%, up five basis points from the second quarter, driven by higher investment yields and lower deposit costs. In the third quarter, we had $800 million more in securities on average than in the second quarter. 
We made investments of $500 million in callable agencies at the holding company and an additional $300 million of 15-year agency mortgage-backed pass-throughs at the bank. The duration of the securities portfolio declined slightly to 2.36 years. 
Despite the investments, we remained highly asset-sensitive such that earnings will increase by $40 million annually for every 100 basis point increase in the fed funds rate. 
Moving on to Slide 6. NPAs increased to 2.18% from 2.01% of loans in REO. Compared to the second quarter average of our peer group in Top 50 banks, however, our ratio is less than half their levels. We continue to feel comfortable with our asset quality in the current environment. 
On Slide 7, in the Commercial and Equipment Financing segment, while NPLs increased 10 basis points, net charge-offs in the Commercial and Equipment Financing segment dropped to 37 basis points annualized for the quarter from 92 basis points last quarter. This equates to $4.7 million in the third quarter versus $11.7 million in the second quarter for a $7 million decline. 
This is actually a good moment to reflect on the lumpiness we discussed last quarter. Given our low level of charge-offs as a starting point, a single creditor too can cause the annualized charge-offs in any one quarter to move meaningfully. Last quarter, that movement in this category was up. And this quarter in this category, the movement was down. 
Page 13 of the press release itemizes charge-off levels by loan category. And you'll notice that within the Equipment Finance subsegment, charge-offs declined to $1.6 million this quarter from $3.7 million in the second quarter. 
On Slide 8, you can see a breakout of our commercial real estate credit performance. And NPAs were 1.55%, compared to 1.23% in the second quarter, while NCOs rose to 98 basis points from 35 basis points as a result of the two construction projects. This equates to $13.5 million in the third quarter versus $4.8 million in the second quarter for an $8.7 million increase. It's worth noting that fully 99% of the commercial real estate charge-offs in this quarter were construction related. And in fact, year-to-date, 94% of commercial real estate charge-offs have been in construction. Our portfolio remains well diversified, and we believe we'll continue to see strong portfolio growth opportunities. 
Slide 9 illustrates our residential loan credit performance. As you can see, our NPLs have increased to 3.67%. Unfortunately, nonperforming residential mortgage resolution continues to take much longer than previously as a result of a much slower foreclosure process in the courts. 
Our loss content has been low, as you can see in the bottom chart, and we believe itll continue to be at low levels because we have low loan to value at originations, and because approximately 85% of our nonperforming loans have current loan to values of less than 90%. We feel good about the residential mortgage pipeline of originations. 
On Slide 10, you can see our Home Equity nonperforming loans continue at low levels comparable to those in the second quarter. Our net charge-offs were up a bit at 26 basis points, but still significantly below industry levels. Utilization rates remain stable at 49%.  We continue to feel the Home Equity offering is an important part of our retail customer relationships. 
Slide 11 reflects our charge-off experience over the past few years. We believe that the range over the last three to four quarters is consistent with the current weak economic environment. And year-to-date, our charge-offs have averaged 43 basis points. 
Slide 12 speaks to our competitive advantage relative to the industry with regard to asset quality and capital. And with that, I'll now hand it back to Jack to wrap it up before we open it up for your questions.

headline: People's United Financial Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Paul. In summary on Slide 13, we believe we continue to offer a compelling investment opportunity. We operate from a position of competitive strength and intend to enhance this position by continuing to focus on improving our operating performance
componenttext:
Thanks, Paul. In summary on Slide 13, we believe we continue to offer a compelling investment opportunity. We operate from a position of competitive strength and intend to enhance this position by continuing to focus on improving our operating performance. We'll continue to pursue capital deployment through well-priced acquisitions, while maintaining a strong dividend and evaluating the returns available from share repurchases.  Further, given the multiyear deleveraging process and the increased regulatory pressures in the sector, we believe potential partners are becoming more interested in combination discussions. 
Finally, we are significantly more asset-sensitive than our peers. So when rates finally do rise, we will have a disproportionate positive impact on our interest income. This concludes our presentation, and now we'll be happy to answer any questions you might have.
